I would still be there with you now, if the sun hadn't intruded on us, and the city hadn't stirred for the day.
That was something I had dreamed about for some time... and now I realise just how woefully meagre my dreams were, compared to the reality.
As I discovered. It isn't so often that the bear is the one being eyed hungrily.
I am glad you have reconsidered, but please don't trivially bring up such difficult topics. My heart can be wounded just like any other.
I warned you to not broach such matters lightly. Perhaps you care less for me than I supposed...
Why would you test my patience like this? Sometimes it is difficult to love you.
I will remain by your side whenever you wish, of course. As ally, advisor, friend... in any way you desire, save for as a lover.
Then... very well. This chapter is at an end. I can only hope you have many more, each filled with happiness.
I see... if that is truly your desire, then I shall respect it. No matter how much I wish it was not the case.
You have said as much to me before, only to change your mind. I told you your heart is your own, but I do not wish for mine to be toyed with. Are you certain?
Was there something else you wanted, my heart?
Come here to me...
Does it please you to see me crestfallen? That is the only reason I can think why you might toy with my heart like this.
Perhaps fate will afford us more time together - I hope it does.
Nor I. At my age, I've come to see that little is worth regretting in the long run, apart from regrets themselves.
I can imagine. You rode out the storm most admirably.
Yes... I hope so. But we have a battle to win, before any of that.
Listen to me, preaching like an initiate in his cups.
I wish... I wish there was a better way. I wish everyone could see the sun, have a full belly, and know nature as a friend. There is a balance that is yet to be found.
All that potential is too often destined to die in the dark, and rot in the gutter.
...and still it draws them in. The safety of numbers. The promise of civilisation. The dream of better.
The city is like a forest with an overgrown canopy. Light and nourishment cannot penetrate to those who need it the most...
Still, though... this place crawls with life, but little of it flourishes. I see refugees, unhoused. The destitute, unwanted. Orphans, unloved.
The city, you mean? With all its noise, smoke, stone, and bustle? I would not be here, given the choice... but I promised you my support. And that is what you shall have.
But in either case, it seems I was insensible for much of my ordeal. Small mercies.
Impressive that she managed to move my bulk, come to think of it. I wonder how that was managed.
Just my pride - I can't believe I allowed myself to be knocked unconscious and spirited away like that...
Oak Father preserve you.
I trust your leadership, and respect your decisions... but I truly hope this is not something we come to regret.
I hope this does not prove to be a mistake, my love.
When I first met you, saving yourself from ceremorphosis was your greatest wish... yet now you have stepped closer to embracing it.
Of course.
Perhaps our time has not yet come. Perhaps dealing with the Absolute must come first. Whatever you decide, I will understand.
A short night, at that. I am sorry if I came on too strongly. Take all the time and space you require.
Of course... That is your right.
I was hoping you would ask...
Indeed, I am but one of your lovers. You and I should each seek happiness, wherever it lies. You are all I want, but I will not hoard you to myself. Let others know the happiness of being with you.
Relationship? Such terms belong to civilisation - a little unfamiliar to my lips. You know what we share is more fluid, more founded in the principles of nature.
You should feel free to roam as your heart desires. You are all I want, but I will not hoard you to myself. Let others know the happiness of being with you.
This need not be a parting, so long as you fight on. You and I can each roam apart, until nature compels our paths to cross once again.
Do as you must, as shall I. We shall meet again. It is as sure as the break of dawn, or the spring thaw.
You are afraid because you are alive, and you have something to lose. Hold on to that.
I have responsibilities. People who are counting on me. But perhaps given time, their roots will grow strong enough that they can stand without me.
If this is what you truly want... I shall respect your wishes. But know that you shall not die - not truly. Nature's realm shall be yours. In the air, the trees, the waters.
You shall live on. And wherever I go, I shall feel your presence, and you mine.
Karlach - you are in pain. Do not say otherwise. It is writ large across your face.
And so you shall, as soon as you come to visit - there will be much for you to see, and not a soul among our numbers who will not wish to praise the saviour of Baldur's Gate.
We are each free, as we always were... but that does not need to be the end.
I wish we had been afforded more time together, but there is so much to do in the wake of the Absolute's defeat, and precious few hands with which to do it.
I cannot. No matter how much I want to.
When we joined battle for the last time, I did not want to presume we would survive. I assumed it might cost us our lives in order to save nature's realm.
I thought that would be the steepest price that could be asked of us. But I was wrong.

You made a choice that would cause most to tremble. You made a sacrifice far greater than merely laying down your life. Your whole future, utterly altered. The world is in your debt, and I am in awe of you.
You need to remove yourself from that danger - go wherever you can find solitude, peace. Nature's realm is vast - it shall provide a place where you can be yourself.
A sorry prize, yes. One that I wish was not so... but the world has a narrow view of who can be its saviour.
But I know what you did. I shall not forget, and I shall make it my purpose to tell all of what you did for them.
I can start to do so almost immediately - the wars of late have left many with nowhere to turn... Many lost their families, their homes - some never had them to begin with.

Perhaps in time, I can trust them to meet their saviour. Perhaps you can come to visit us, and be treated with all the reverence you deserve. That day may be distant. But I shall do everything in my power to hasten it.
I could seek you out, or you could return to me, if Avernus were to yield a cure.
You are right. But such... drastic times can make it difficult to preserve nuance in one's thinking. Further reflection is needed.
At least... for now, they depend on me. But perhaps given time, their roots will grow strong enough that they can stand without me.
You can still save yourself, Karlach. You can return to Avernus. It need not be forever. Just long enough to give yourself a chance.
We have challenges to surmount, of course, but with you by my side, my heart stays strong.
This place is... not for me, perhaps. But with you by my side, and the shadow curse a fading memory, I shall keep my head high.
This city troubles me... but I am here for you. I want to be by your side, and see this through.
My mind still drifts to that dream I shared with you, for a better future for all those who need it... but that must wait. I remain yours, of course. Ready when you need me.
With the end upon us? So long as I am surviving, and I have you by my side, I am faring as well as anyone can be.
You wish to speak? I am here for you.
All of nature's bounty pales next to you. Do you need something?
Speak to me, lover.
My heart soars just to look upon you. What do you need?
Thaniel still needs our help - part of his essence must still be out there, somewhere.
We should return to camp when we can - I must see how Thaniel is faring. With the Oak Father's blessing, the shadow curse may soon be no more.
It is done - now Thaniel will be whole again. I could not have done this without you, my friend.
Then I will watch the horizon for you each day, and fix your image in my mind each night, until I feel your touch again.
You are right, of course. There are no mistakes in nature - it is all a grand tapestry beyond mortal reckoning.
You live your life, and I shall live mine... but forgive me the odd hopeful glance towards the horizon, in search for you.
Have no fear. I am exceedingly patient.
I see... After all my years of living, I know all too well that nothing lasts forever. Yet a parting can sting, nonetheless.
But that just means what we shared was precious, and will live on in my memory. Thank you - I am a richer man for having met you.
Of course - somehow I'd hoped for a miracle. But of course, the only miracles are those we make ourselves.
To Avernus? The land of lost souls...? I cannot. There are people who depend on me now.
My. Perhaps a tale for the older children, once I trim off a few of the... less savoury details. But thank you, all the same.
In a manner of speaking, yes... Though it is a more complex, evolving beast than I could ever have anticipated. True balance is no simple, fixed thing. I see that now.
You are truly incapable of disappointing. The children shall be rapt - and have no fear; all due credit shall be given to the tale's originator.
Indeed? I had feared a life in service of Shar might have narrowed her mind, but I am glad to be proven wrong. There is more to her than even she knows, I feel.
Indeed? Perhaps it was naive of me to even wonder if she would mind. Her culture arose from the distant fringes of nature, after all. But it gladdens me, all the same.
Truly? This is most welcome news. She must be as strong in spirit as she is in body.
Somehow, I am not the least part surprised - but I am glad.
Did you find time to speak with your partner? A potentially delicate topic, I understand.
Is this truly what progress looks like?
I... you are right. I cannot repeat her mistakes.
Thank you - your wisdom shines through even in dark moments. I shall not give in to despair. Not while there is still the chance of a future worth fighting for.
You speak nothing but the truth. The Shadow Druids' words are meant to inflame those already given to anger and helplessness - I do not want to join their ranks.
A fine point. I wish I had thought of it myself.
Indeed. But I cannot shake it from my mind, all the same...
I do... but at times like this, it can feel like an impossible dream.
Sometimes it is difficult to see exactly what we are fighting to save here. Sometimes it feels like Kagha was right - nature can only survive away from all this...
Sometimes it is difficult to see exactly what we are fighting to save here. Sometimes the Shadow Druids' desire to separate nature from all this seems pragmatic, not fanatical...
Her will is strong - even now, she defies the bounds of the material plane. She will prevail.
You saw how they wished to burn the clothes of a child? As if being crammed in this very city is not the cause of lice and disease?
Unnatural steel beings patrol the streets, the printed word sows discontent, and those in need are treated with disdain.
I had hoped there might be a greater sense of balance within the city - that its walls might enable sheltering within it to foster community, peace... yet it is not so.
I was all too eager to surrender my responsibilities towards the grove... and now it has been sealed away from the world. Perhaps I was never meant to be Archdruid - to be a leader.
This is welcome news. Most welcome.
Indeed. But I have roamed far and wide for years - whole lifetimes. I have seen much, done much, learned much. It would be a shame to not pass that on.
Now we will have each other, but not just each other. Our hearts are free to roam, together or apart, as nature designed.
Now? Now I need to restrain myself, until we are afforded a quiet moment. Seek your bedroll when you are ready - but do not expect much sleep.
Moonrise Towers. Many druids and Harpers died to take this place once... only for Ketheric Thorm to rule it once again.
Orin has made off with Gale - we must rescue him... unless you wish to kill Gortash for her.
Vampire spawn assailing us in the night? I thought we had ample troubles as it was. At least Astarion is safe.
Vampire spawn assailing us in the night? I thought we had ample troubles as it was. At least you are safe, Astarion.
Our work is not yet finished - not until Ketheric Thorm's last breath flees his corpse. Let us pursue him.
This orb... Gale carries a most dire burden. I wish he had shared it with us sooner.
You carry a most dire burden inside you, Gale. I wish you had shared it with us sooner.
Astarion... he has ascended amongst the ranks of the undead. I can only hope that he does not come to regret the price that he paid.
A cruel parting of ways with Shadowheart. I can only hope the allies we have won will be worth our betrayal.
A shame that Minsc had to die. I sense he could have been an ally to us, had circumstances been different.
Zevlor turned to darkness in his desperation... but he did not deserve a fate such as that.
Of course. Take your time - some things should not be rushed.
Go to your bedroll when you're ready. But do not expect to get much sleep.
In either case, I will remain by your side for whatever you need of me. Until the very end.
Still... I could not have forgiven myself had I not taken the plunge. Better to have tried and failed.
I understand, and I still cherish our relationship.
I cannot blame them. It is understandable why someone would want to keep you all to themselves, even if it is not my way.
Now? Now you must rest. For the moment that engine of yours is fixed, I doubt you'll be getting very much sleep at all.
The feeling is more than mutual. Now: you must rest. And in the morning, we must get that engine of yours fixed. The moment I am able to touch you will be... memorable. For us both, I hope.
The feeling is more than mutual. Seek your bedroll when you are ready - but do not expect much sleep.
A temple dedicated to Shar. More than a temple perhaps - a proving ground. This must be where Ketheric Thorm grew his dark-cloaked ranks.
I thought that would be the case once... yet perhaps the grove will not need me.
Forgive me. The shadow curse occupied me so entirely and for so long... I almost miss the purpose it gave me. Now I must find a new one.
Ah, there it is. That is what I have been missing.
Now, we have much to catch up on. Do not allow me to ramble on - I am eager to hear all you have been doing.
In that case, very well.

Our community grows rapidly; in six months, we have turned what was once a shadowy wasteland into a true home for all. In another six months, I would wager the scars of the past will be entirely invisible even to those who remember them.
The old masonry of Moonrise Towers and Reithwin have been repurposed into new homes, and the land is rich with harvests and bountiful trees. Nature and civilisation are in harmony, stronger together.
It is, truly... though a more complex, evolving beast than I could ever have anticipated. I spoke often of balance before; only now do I realise that balance is no simple, fixed thing.

We welcome folk from all walks of life - anyone who wishes for a new start. Naturally, it can be chaotic at times, but it is a thrilling sort of chaos. It thrives in ways I could never have dreamed of.
You are welcome whenever you like and for however long as you please.
As am I. I may age more slowly than most, but I do believe I've gained some new laughter lines of late.
Now please, tell me all, and spare no details. I shall not lie - I have an ulterior motive in wishing to hear all. It is the children, you see. My charges.
Please, spare no details. I shall not lie - I have an ulterior motive in wishing to hear all. It is the children, you see. My charges.
Their appetite for bedtime tales is greater than I could ever have anticipated: 'Another story, Daddy Halsin, another!' is the chorus that greets me each nightfall.
They have all but exhausted my repertoire in but a few short months - no mean feat, given the lifetime I have lived. I desperately need new material, please. My reputation is at stake.
Ha! You would ask to be tucked in next. But whatever the intrepid adventurer needed, I would have been glad to provide.
More than a few, I should think. At least I shall be equipped to explain the birds and the bees when the time comes, but I hope that time is quite a while off yet.
I am all ears. Though I never cared for that phrase. A rather unsettling image...
You have kept yourself busy - I expected no less, in truth.
I shall be able to keep the children enthralled for a few more nights yet, thanks to you. And should you wish to retell of your exploits in person? Well, I shall not object to a night off.
Now, it would be cruel of me to hoard you all to myself for the evening, as much as I would like to. I shall leave you to the others for now, unless there was anything else?
How thoughtless of me. Come here...
As am I. I can scarcely imagine life without your company now, and of course I made a promise to help you - one I intend to fulfil.
That was more than worth the wait.
I know it can, for I feel the longing for old friends in my heart each day.
Still, though... I cannot help but wonder if there was more I could have done. Perhaps, Oak Father willing, I may yet have the chance some day...
I was all too eager to surrender my responsibilities towards the grove. Perhaps I was never meant to be Archdruid - to be a leader.

That is where true leadership lies - not in winning a single vast battle, but in fighting a thousand smaller ones. Making ten thousand difficult decisions. Finding balance, where none seems possible, day after day...
One grand victory may not be enough to absolve a host of small failures.
There have been difficulties - some initiates harbour too much admiration for Kagha's course of action. Francesca will do what she must to rid them of such notions.
Wounds have healed, damage has been undone... balance has been restored. Those who seek to serve nature there can once again do so, with all their hearts.
She is well-suited to the task - better than I, perhaps. To cleanse a land of shadows is one thing, but to sway a heart from a dark path is another matter entirely...
Francesca has found some initiates still yearn for the false promises the Shadow Druids peddled. She has been working hard to show them the error of their ways.
The Shadow Druids. Their scheming was stopped, thanks to you... yet their malign ideals can find purchase and live on, even after the instigators themselves are vanquished.
My chosen successor, Francesca, has proven to be a wise choice. Perhaps the wisest I ever made as Archdruid.
I received a dispatch from the grove. Life carries on there in our absence, just as nature intended.
Devastation beyond measure... We must prevail. We must heal the damage that has been wrought.
It truly is splendid to see everyone gathered together again, if only for a night. I hope the sun does not make haste to rise on us.
You would think someone of my vintage would be inured to the passage of time, yet these past six months have seemed endless without your company. But now our paths cross once more...
... Just as I hoped they would, more like. The Oak Father has been kind to me this past while, yet I cannot forget the bond we all forged together.
In any case, my audience will favour a good tale over veracity any day - I thank you for your offering.
It is one that can weather any distance, any passage of time. I know it can, for I feel the longing for old friends in my heart each day.
We have all pined for each other's company, I sense. I cannot imagine otherwise, after what we shared.
That bond was forged in a crucible that can never be stoked again, Oak Father willing. It is a bond that can weather any distance, any passage of time.
I always do. Should I ever decline, assume a doppelganger has taken my place.
Quite often - they come and go as they please, but with so many playmates to avail of, they are far from strangers.
The belly of the city. How many people are born, live, and die within these walls without ever seeing the depths of nature's beauty for themselves? I shudder to think.
There is something foul to to air here - it reeks of madness and death.
It seems Gale has made amends with Mystra. I see this as a good omen for what awaits us.
Alfira died badly. I can only hope the others that share this campfire do not share her fate...
Will Orin truly free Lae'zel if we slay Gortash? I am not so sure... a rescue may be in order.
I am sorry, Gale. You tried. Mystra was wrong to turn on you, no matter what mistakes you made in the past.
A pact made with Raphael will surely bring nothing but misfortune, as much as I would like to be proven wrong.
Shadowheart truly is Shar's instrument now. At least perhaps her new dark-cloaked followers can help in the fight against the Absolute.
Shadowheart... you truly are Shar's instrument now. At least perhaps your dark-cloaked followers may prove of service against the Absolute.
Wyll intends to take the fight to the very Hells themselves? I can think of no one more capable.
You are taking the fight to the very Hells themselves, Wyll? I can think of none more capable.
I fought proudly alongside Harpers once... but it seems we cannot place our trust in them now - not while Orin has their ranks infiltrated.
Shadow magic, Gale...? No matter how desperate times become, you should not defile yourself with such foul matters. You are better than that.
Mystra would ask for Gale's life in return for forgiveness...? A cruel demand to make of a mortal.
It may be some centuries before my flesh is ready to yield, but I hope I shall be bold enough to follow in her path, when the day comes.
Jaheira's wisdom is plain to see. One of the greatest ways in which you can serve nature is to surrender your body back to it, when the time comes.
Mizora schemes with Wyll's very freedom. He deserves to know what she is up to.
Mizora has something planned for you, Wyll. I could see it in her eyes... and I fear it does not bode well.
Yet, she fears there are none to inherit her work, so she goes on. Long life can be a burden at times - I know that well.
Jaheira's wisdom is plain to see. She understands that to truly serve nature, you must one day surrender your body back to it.
Vlaakith's words have set Lae'zel's mind, it seems. I would not wish to be the one that the Lich Queen unleashes her upon.
I thought your faith in Vlaakith was unshakeable, Lae'zel. Perhaps Voss will prove to be a more worthy ally.
Your queen's words have set your mind then, Lae'zel? I would not wish to be the one that Vlaakith unleashes you upon.
I thought Lae'zel's faith in Vlaakith was unshakeable. Perhaps Voss shall prove to be a more worthy ally to her.
I can already sense the first stirrings of new life in the land. The grip of the curse is weakening - now we must break it, once and for all.
Not a decision you have made lightly, I trust. You have my support, no matter what.
What are you thinking?
But let us not forget that we also have the Orphic Hammer. We could free Orpheus, let him wield the stones - if we can trust him.
Karlach has offered to take up the mantle. I think you should let her have her wish. Her time is short, but she can live on in all the hearts of those she will have saved.
So, only a mind flayer can wield the stones, if you trust the Emperor's word.
So, only a mind flayer can wield the stones, if you trust the Emperor's word. You are already part-illithid, but this is a whole other matter...
A lair of undeath - most unnatural. We must tread carefully.
A curious discovery, this place. This city builds and builds upon itself, until it forgets its own secrets.
Defying a goddess, Gale? And one you have known so intimately? I hope you do not come to regret this.
Last Light fell because you could not control the violence in your heart. All those people perished because of what you did to Isobel. You must try harder. You must be better.
Wyll sacrificed his own father... a hard choice, but not one that is unknown in nature. At times, a seedling must strangle the very tree that bore it, if it is to survive.
You made a hard choice, Wyll. But not one that is unknown in nature. At times, a seedling must strangle the very tree that bore it, if it is to survive.
Poor Gale... but Mystra is wrong about him. Perhaps he can yet prove that.
I am sorry, Gale... but Mystra is wrong about you. Perhaps you can yet prove that.
Shadowheart's true nature won out in the end, no matter how much Shar tried to bury it. It gladdens my heart to see a family reunited.
Shadowheart. To turn from Shar cannot have been easy... but having your family by your side shows you did what was right.
The final battle is upon us. May the Oak Father grant us victory.
For so long, we have fought the Absolute... only to now learn you were once one of its masterminds? There is nothing we can take for granted.
I had hoped you would shun Bhaal's overtures... but those hopes are dashed. To be a vessel for murder itself? I can think of few things less natural.
It seems you have made amends with Mystra, Gale. Congratulations. I see this as a good omen for what awaits us.
Lorroakan hunts powerful game - too powerful for him, perhaps. Dame Aylin should be informed that yet another ambitious fool lusts after her.
Karlach's rage is like a force of nature. I pity those who bear its brunt.
Wyll sacrificed a great deal for his family. The pact may stand, but the strength of his character is clear.
Mystra has forsaken Gale entirely. A crushing blow... but he is strong enough to persevere, I think.
Astarion... you have ascended amongst the ranks of the undead. I can only hope that you do not come to regret the price that you paid.
A pity. I sensed a love of nature and animals in her. There may have been more to her than even she knew of.
I am unsure if Shadowheart would have remained committed to the darkness, if put to the test... but we did not afford her the chance to decide.
Shar's ire has shaken Shadowheart... and yet she goes on. There is untold strength there, I feel.
You faced the scorn of a goddess, and still draw breath. That is an uncommon feat, Shadowheart.
Those vampire spawn made off with Astarion. It shall fall to us to rescue him.
A hammer capable of shattering the bonds in the Astral Plane? That sounds like something we should seek out.
A city within a city, older as you go deeper. Much like the rings of a tree.
Karlach has had her mortality defined to her in most cruel terms... I do not know if we can help her, but perhaps we can at least be there for her.
Gale, you truly thought to turn to shadow magic, after seeing how it has ravaged nature? Your ambitions are... disquieting.
I was never afforded a chance to start a family of my own - serving nature always had to come first.
Jaheira's family is a credit to her - she is wise to keep them secret, safe.
Astarion resisted the allure of Cazador's would-be powers - and I am glad of it. Whatever he would have gained would have come at a great price.
You resisted the allure of Cazador's would-be powers? I am glad. Whatever there was to gain would have come at a great price.
Gale defied Mystra herself. I hope he does not come to regret it.
Shar sought rob Shadowheart of her family - of her true nature. But no more. Now the  healing can begin.
You were wise to turn from Shar, Shadowheart. Now your family is restored, and the healing can begin.
Orin has taken Yenna. We must free her - either by force, or by paying for her freedom with Gortash's life.
Shadowheart... fulfilling your parents' wishes took courage beyond measure. I hope true peace finds its way to you swiftly.
Your rage is most impressive, Karlach. If the lesson is to not provoke your temper, consider it well-learned.
A cruel task fell to Shadowheart... but she did as her parents wished. She has my eternal respect, and I hope she soon finds peace.
It is no small thing, to defy a goddess. Perhaps the darkness is not Shadowheart's true nature.
You sacrificed a great deal for your family, Wyll. The pact may stand, but the strength of your character is clear.
Gortash's bluster will no longer assail our ears. And we have his Netherstone also - soon we shall unravel this unnatural conspiracy, once and for all.
That... creature you changed into. I pray to Silvanus that you have it under control.
This place is unnatural in ways I cannot truly fathom - a vile celebration of death without purpose.
I cannot imagine how you are feeling, Gale. For a goddess to ask a mortal to pay such a price... I am sorry for, for your burden.
We allowed Astarion to sacrifice so many, only to just turn on him soon after? We should have stopped him sooner.
Mizora dead... and Wyll, doomed to the Hells. Oak Father, lend him your strength.
I cannot imagine how you are feeling, Gale. For a goddess to ask a mortal to pay such a price. I am sorry for, for your burden... though I wish you had told us of your predicament before.
Minsc has great heart - we shall need the likes of him, for the trials to come.
Minsc believes a doppelganger to be Jaheira? He is being manipulated - I am all but certain.
Karlach... I am sorry. I shall not try to soothe you with gilded words, but know that I am here for you.
Once, you would have to sway hearts in order to raise an army... but with this place? Any tyrant could lay claim to legions of artificial killers.
Your self-discipline has been rewarded, I think. Perhaps Mystra is more invested in your survival than you might believe...
Lae'zel's faith in her queen is unshakeable, it seems. I just hope Vlaakith recognises that.
Your loyalty stands to you, Lae'zel. I can only hope Vlaakith recognises it as I do.
It seems that Wyll's determined to remain the Blade of Frontiers. I suppose he's truly earned the moniker, now.
So, you've committed to being the Blade of Frontiers. None can doubt you've earned the title. Well done.
Nature cares little for nobility - it is pure artifice - but I can still hold some respect for Wyll's accomplishment. He shall be a fine Duke, I am sure.
Nature cares little for nobility - it is pure artifice - but I can still respect your achievement, Wyll. You shall be a fine Duke, I am sure.
To defy a goddess is no small thing, Shadowheart. Perhaps the darkness is not your true nature.
They ask after you often. What you did for them will never be forgotten - I can see it in the land all around me, but more importantly, I see it in their faces whenever they visit.
I warned you - told you this was my burden to carry. Why didn't you listen?
Ornaments, utensils - and ducks. I like ducks.
You are... nothing if not inventive. I can only hope the foe had already expired before you began your work.
Ah, but there are no pets in nature - only companions. Though I'll admit Crag likely made for a rather stoic confidante...
Is that so? Would you seek to drizzle honey on a neck before indulging?
Ha! Talented from the beginning, then? Almost a surprise you didn't cast magic in the womb.
I shall need to think on it for a while.
But it heartens me to learn you and I share the same admiration.
Ha! Pet ownership is an illusion - nature's creatures choose their own companions. No one has true mastery over them in the end. As it should be.
I think I know how you feel... duty, eh? I hope your wish comes true. We'll need new life once all this is over.
Luckily there's nothing small about getting to know someone like you. There's little occasion for frivolity in nature - I can appreciate your stance... even if others do not.
Thank me by returning the favour, why don't you? Come on - I've sure you've got something better than carving wooden ducks.
That was amazing.
350 years young. I've been privileged to watch saplings grow into mighty boughs.
You're right. Sometimes I think people look at me and imagine my feelings can't be hurt.
Well they are fierce creatures from what I understand... but as long as you avoid the high seas, I think you can consider yourself safe.
That was terrible.
I like what I like. Once you get to my age, you realise there's little point in denying yourself, so long as others aren't affected.
What would you like to know?
I know, I know; well-trodden territory. Well, let's see... I whittle in my spare time, and I've something of a sweet tooth - though everyone's very amused when I say I like honey.
Let us talk later.
Hmm, I suppose you wouldn't be shocked to learn I love animals and nature?
The same's true of everyone, I find.

Well, I didn't pick this scar up in battle. I was in wildshape, only I forgot it was the season when bears are particularly social. A she-bear claimed me as her own - and did not appreciate being spurned.
Right now? I bed down alone, I'm afraid. Perhaps once I talk less of curses and parasites, my fortunes will improve.
I'm 350 years old. Of course there have been lovers. Just because I love nature doesn't mean I'm betrothed to it. Though sometimes, nature needs reminding...
I hope so. But I won't turn my back on the past - it made me who am I today.
It was a long time ago. The wounds don't heal, but they become more bearable.
Save for me, my line perished a long time ago. They rest in High Forest now, near the shade of the Grandfather Tree. The grove became my family, with Silvanus as my teacher. And now, I have you.
You're not a doppelganger, are you? Trying to study me, learn all my secrets so you can take my place?
Not just now. I need a moment.
I'm afraid there's not much I can say - I've sworn confidence to someone already.
You wish to speak? Fine.
What do you want?
Thank me by returning the favour, why don't you? Come on - I've sure you've got all sorts you could tell me.
Oh. Well, your choice, of course.
Druids and Harpers joined together to put a stop to Ketheric Thorm. We marched on Moonrise and, after much fighting, we prevailed.
Even in defeat, though, Ketheric turned to Shar. Not long after we sealed him away in his tomb, the shadow curse took hold. No one had seen the likes of it before. No one knew how to react...
...Then it started to claim all those within its reach. Those who had survived the battles now fell to the shadows - became part of the shadows. And worst of all... I lost contact with Thaniel.
I wanted to try and find him, but we couldn't stay - we would have all succumbed. When the Archdruid of the Grove - my predecessor - was seized by the curse, I had to lead the survivors to safety.
That was my first day as Archdruid. An inauspicious beginning.
Indeed. I know that all too well.
You're right. But the work is not yet done - not while Ketheric Thorm still draws breath.
You're right. I should not let the failures of the past sour the victories of the present. We have achieved something immense here.
I will never forget your part in this. Nor will Thaniel.
I see... Foolhardy, perhaps, to reveal such a thing to a veteran of battles against Shar worshippers. Foolhardy... or brave.
I have no love for your goddess, or the foul things she unleashed upon nature. But I can appreciate your honesty. There is nobility in your conduct, if not in your allegiance.
A Shar worshipper... I see. It can't have been easy for you to tell me such a thing, given my history. But I am glad you took the plunge.
A Shar worshipper... I see. Perhaps you feared how I would react, but still... you should have told me sooner.
You were not even born when Shar's followers slew my fellow druids, or when her shadow curse tainted the land. I can get past those... but I truly wish you had trusted me sooner.
You are lucky that we share common purpose. In most other cases, this revelation would put us on opposite sides of the battlefield.
No... nothing of the sort. But that is not to say it isn't connected. Best be careful, all the same.
The urge to kill is common in nature - for some creatures it is the core of their being... Still, though, you seem to speak of a darker impulse. Be careful how it manifests itself.
You are a mortal child of Bhaal? Be careful with whom you share that fact - I hear many of your kind have met premature ends.
And a hard-won freedom at that. Well done.
Nature bows to none. It will fight on and survive, no matter what madness your god has inspired you to undertake.
It seems like you've no room for me just now - and I take up no small amount of space.
Then you'll have me. Lead on.
We need to keep our guard up - those brigands got too close to use for my liking.
Nature has been most kind to let me share in your heart. What do you need?
You truly are a feast for my eyes - nature outdid itself with you. Did you wish to speak?
I have longed to hear your voice. Speak to me.
What word, my love?
I knew then that I had to be more than a companion to him. I had to be a protector.
It was Thaniel, of course. Nature was my very first friend. I get older, but he hasn't changed a day.
Any time.
It's a natural question, but I don't have a good answer, I'm afraid. Perhaps there's a half-orc buried somewhere in my ancestry.
Do you truly even need to ask? Of course! Who could not open their home to a befeathered hero of Baldur's Gate?
I know we can. Think of all that we've already survived. Our foes should quake to see us approach them.
All this devastation... but we shall prevail, my love. We shall vanquish this blight, and watch the healing unfold.
And I did promise the children I would bring them back a surprise... imagine their faces.
I was just thinking the very same.
If only we could stay like that forever.
Your embrace makes me feel safer than any armour could.
I could get used to this.
It's true, and I can't imagine I helped with that. Sometimes I let the task at hand consume me, and people think I'm obsessed.
Don't worry yourself about what I think just yet - we may not have spent much time in each other's company yet, but I joined you because your judgement seems sound.
Honestly...? I'd hoped for more from you. But perhaps things can yet be turned around.
I shall never tire of that.
Nor would I.
Just a token to remember me by. Now I've taken up enough of your time - go on, enjoy the festivities. We can speak again later.
No. It's wooden. I suppose it burns if you find yourself in dire need of kindling, but I hope it does not come to that.
I had a friend when I was young, long ago. He played with me in the forests where I grew up... but eventually, I realised no one else had heard of him.
Given the circumstances? You're faring as well as can be expected, I suppose.
Victory eludes us, my love. But let us press on - the stones may have failed us, but this is not over while we still draw breath.
...but honestly? You've surpassed even those. Seems my faith was more than well-founded.
The day I weary of those lips is the day I weary of life.
Yet they always find their way back to where they belong, just like old friends find themselves back in each other's company.
Ducks are my favourite, but I thought they were particularly fitting in this case. They are migratory birds of course, travelling far and wide with the turn of the seasons.
I was hoping you'd ask.
I've been unfair to you - I've had unrealistic expectations of your character ever since I joined you...
Before you go, I have something for you - just a little keepsake really. Do you remember how I told you I like to whittle? I made this...
Even Kagha may yet find true balance, thanks to her influence.
Kagha was beyond saving, but the others have a true mentor now. And I am very glad for them.
You are more intoxicating than any fare this gathering has to offer.
A cruel choice lies before you. I can only speculate how you must feel.
Trust me, it's been said. You've shown more restraint than most in avoiding the subject until now.
Well... that is your choice to make, of course. Though I hope the sentimental value may win out over the temptation of a few coppers...
Who is to say? Perhaps there's a half-orc buried somewhere in my ancestry?
Oh, I am well aware, trust me. Now I've taken up enough of your time - go on, enjoy the festivities.
I want to talk about what happened.
I had hoped the stones would have ensured our victory by now, but it was not to be. Let us press on - this is not over while we still draw breath.
This is it, my friend. One last battle to decide all...
Or perhaps not - sometimes I think conventional wisdom is too narrow about what someone can or cannot be. Stranger things have most certainly happened.
I spend half my days in ursine form - the children demand it! I had a score of them taking turns riding upon my back just days ago.
On occasion, but I prefer not to interfere. Francesca of the High Forest is Archdruid now, and by all accounts, she has proven to be a steady and wise influence.
But I know that you, above all, are sure to make the right choice.
Now I've taken up enough of your time - go on, enjoy the festivities. We can speak again later.
To make a child smile is to dabble with the power of gods, as far as I am concerned.
Of course. But it shall not be the last...
Nothing remains for us here. Let us leave, and seek out the final reckoning.
We shall triumph. Our time together does not end here.
The end is upon us, my love. One last battle to decide all...
I am glad they are so comfortable with the Oak Father's creations, but they must learn that not all are as amiable as I am. A lesson for another time though; they deserve some joy.
The sight is unnatural, but I can look past the form, to the spirit within. You did this for all of us - I am indebted, not repulsed.
As for roaming... that impulse has dwindled, I must admit. Perhaps because I have found where I am meant to be.
As did I... but somehow I feel like I no longer need to roam - that I have found something worthy laying roots for.
Amazing, what can be discovered about oneself, even at a ripe old age.
I am?
Trust me, the day I no longer have to talk about the shadow curse will be a happy one. What would you like to know?
The end is upon us, my heart. One last battle to decide all...
Something we can use?
Just observing.
Shake off the dust.
Got it.
Bits and bobs.
Hush this fussing, you're fine.
Looking.
Still some way to go.
What can a worm teach others but how to crawl? Shadowheart has no need of your 'instruction', Viconia.
I imagine she will have something to say about the matter. If we must return, let it be with blades bared.
Done.
They're dead, Entharl. Doppelgangers were using them as bait.
Pay me no mind...
There.
A little further.
Only because I can no longer bear to look you in the eye.
Silvanus soften my steps.
On the trail.
Stalking.
Malar's mark. How many more Harpers dead?
I'm glad you're safe, Entharl. My Harpers - they were replaced by doppelgangers.
Eyes to yourselves.
Shelves stuffed with overpriced arcane trinkets. This place would whet Gale's appetite something fearsome.
Alive. But he'll need some time to recover.
You toss allies aside so easily, after everything? If you are so eager to join this worm, then may you both be buried here together.
Mind who you call history, hollyphant.
Hm?
Boots worn through.
Work to be done.
Still a fight to win.
Always poking, prodding, trying things out...
Nature's servant, and yours.
What about... this.
Let us see.
Would you hand her over to have her wings pulled off by this self-inflated wretch?
Aylin is a friend - to whom we owe our lives, I would remind you.
As I'm told.
What about this.
You get to my age, you have already done everything. Be my guest.
Do not parley with this madman.
What's this, then?
Simple enough.
Alive. But a Harper no more. He's better off out of it.
Am I to sneak up and say 'boo'?
Swiftly, if you please. These knees do not bend easily.
Always nice to be wanted.
Nature's servant awaits.
...A very formal greeting, Geraldus. You are well?
At your back, always.
Show them the warrior I know.
I can spare a moment.
Come, let us free the bard from his adoring fans. And their rather accurate charges.
Come. You're tougher than that.
Care for a bedtime story while you're at it?
Of course we'll save you, Volo. I think this mob has made the rather silly mistake of taking you seriously.
Oh come now, you cannot be spent already?
Still alive? Good.
Not done yet.
Turn your gaze, lest I turn it for you...
Ssssshhh.
Speak. Up.
Perhap afterwards.
Steps light as falling leaves...
Nature's servant, still waiting.
Oh my, you found me.

You are bold to seek me out after sharing your affections with another.
Are those bite-marks on your neck, or did you contract some unpleasant rash from the vampire?
Of course I am. But you no longer have me, and you never will.
As long as you do not let your lusts distract you from the fight, we do not need to speak of this again.
Hurt me? You aren't capable. But you have disappointed me.
A poor choice.
I can understand why you would choose a Duke's son over an exiled daughter of Menzoberranzan.
You were incapable of raising yourself to my standards - perhaps you will have better fortune lowering yourself to Karlach's.
What little I know of githyanki courtship suggests Lae'zel will not wish to share you. And nor do I.
The wizard? Of all people?
Shadowheart likes to keep secrets, but the two of you could not keep this from me.
I advise you to walk away while you still can.
She will die, you will grieve, and then you will be alone.
If you intend to be with her, do not fool yourself into thinking it is more than a brief dalliance before her fire is extinguished for good.
Unlike Karlach, I will recover.
You should hurry back and warm your hands on her heart. Mine is altogether colder.
If somebody angers me, I hurt them not because I lose control of my temper, but because it teaches them not to anger me again.
If somebody causes me sorrow, I remove their ability to do so again. If that involves removing their head, so be it.
But I do not lash out or strike without reason.
A mistake. I am your most valuable asset.
Of course. I belong in battle.
When you realise your mistake, I will be ready to join you again.
Celebrate our victory. We have earned the Absolute's favour, but She will ask more of us soon.
Begone, insect. I have found somebody more deserving.
The goblins are your responsibility tonight. I have other matters to attend to.
Wait until morning, True Soul. All will be revealed.
She will test you. If you fail, you will break; if your faith is strong, you will become something greater than yourself.
How disappointing for you. I could have shown you ecstasy.
Good. I will join you when you go to your bed. You are mine.
Give your body to me.
If you already have doubts, you would only have disappointed me. Get out of my sight.
Are you ready to give yourself to me?
Celebrate as long as you please, but save your strength. There will be no rest tonight - your body is mine.
Already regretting your decision? I hope you're ready to beg for my company.
Cast off one of the lessers who trail behind you, and I will gladly stand at your side.
Good. I do not like to stand idle.
You look well. Are you ready to pursue our enemies?
I thought you might be in flames the next time I saw you. Karlach's touch has that effect on people.
You have already chosen a distraction for the night, I see.
Then steel yourself. If you are uncertain, you will not even survive the journey.
When we next meet, we will be together in the Absolute's presence, and She will make us Her champions.
Go to him when you are ready. I will lead what remains of my forces to Moonrise ahead of you.
Though I am proud, I prefer exile to death.
I want you as much as I ever did, but our bond is based on ambition as much as affection. I am not sure that our goals still align.
We can survive this together, but I want more - I want us to rule together. To master the brain, and to become Absolute.
Do you have the courage and conviction to do what is needed when the time comes?
I do. But I also know that what I am asking of you is not an easy thing.
When the time comes to take control of the cult, there will only be me and you. Everyone else is expendable.
That is how it must be. You cannot think otherwise.
I cannot. Too often you lack the conviction to make the hard choices.
Show me your resolve in actions, not words.
What would we be then? Survivors, with nothing to show for our struggles but trauma and scars?
Since Moonrise - since you saved me from the cult - I have made it clear to you what I want.
Control. Power. To become Absolute.
I have been open about my intentions because I cannot work with those I do not trust.
And I cannot love those who lack ambition.
If you do not feel the heat of my passion, it is because you no longer ignite it.
I am not cold when I spill the blood of our enemies, or when I dream of conquest.
Be part of those dreams, as you once were, and you will taste my fire again.
And when the fighting began, he led his troops from the front and cut through the enemy like a scythe through stalks.
Blows and arrows rained down on him, and before long his face was a mask of blood. But he did not fall - he did not even falter.
When we won the day, Ketheric's armour was bent and shattered, but his flesh was unmarked.
I have lived long enough to know that few things are impossible in this world.
For my people, to reject Lolth is to reject life. I am apostate, and would be executed.
Ketheric's power is a rare thing though. I have never seen its like.
If you had seen my city's splendour, you would not ask the question. I will miss it until they day I die.
Yes. My House trained me to be a soldier in Lolth's service, and my mother showed me how to survive the perils of society.
You have my sympathy.
I had hoped my influence would help tame your chaotic mind. It appears not.
A disturbing admission. I would rather die than lose control of myself again.
You have never visited?
Most likely.
You are of aristocratic blood? I thought as much.
But whatever House matron you sprang from, your upbringing cannot compare with mine.
I am a Baenre, born into the city's most ancient and powerful house. My life was one of privilege and danger.
Like you, I lived in Qu'ellarz'orl, high above the city's sprawl.
Nonsense.
From the still, dark waters of Lake Donigarten to the black academies of Tier Breche, it is a city of wonders... and terror.
But it is not my home anymore. If I were to return, I would be denied all of its wonders, and shown only the terror.
I am a daughter of Menzoberranzan's most ancient and powerful House, the Baenre. I lived a life of privilege and danger.
My home was at the tallest point of Qu'ellarz'orl, the Place of the Nobles, a plateau high above the city's sprawl.
I enjoyed every luxury, whether harvested in the Underdark or stolen from the surface, and I survived my first assassination attempt while I still suckled at my mother's breast.
I tasted her blood that day. She covered my body with her own, and a blade bit deep into her chest, almost puncturing her heart.
When I came of age, she tried to take my life herself, and I gave her fresh scars to match those she earned protecting me.
I expect so. If the world were to end, I think my mother would survive to rule over the ruins.
She taught me to be resilient, and to guard my heart from those who cannot be trusted. Literally and figuratively.
When I choose to let somebody close, I do not do so lightly.
That gives a great depth of meaning to the bonds I do share.
Yes. Particularly when the home was so magnificent.
There is a connection to this Nighsong of Balthazar's, whatever - or whoever - it might be.
We must find it, and destroy it.
The necromancer Balthazar is Ketheric's chief advisor. One who has mastery over the dead may well be able to help the living cheat it.
We had barely begun to eat when she spoke for the first time. I only caught one word - my name.
Then, quick as lightning, she climbed onto the table, a dagger in each hand, and skipped toward me, slicing the throats out of my men as she passed them.
If it had been an option, I would have.
Few things frighten me. Orin is one of them.
Ketheric held me still. His hand on my shoulder, the grip tight enough to crack the bone.
When Orin stood before me, she touched the dagger to my eye, drawing out a tear of blood.
You've seen the horrors of the colony. Orin kept me there for days. She forced me to watch as my men were processed; some for food, others as thralls.
And then she placed the tadpole in my eye herself.
I was. I deserved what happened to me, for my passivity, for my weakness. For my pride.
You know the rest as well as I do. There were massacres before the Grove - religious communities, mostly. Those who refused to convert.
Then there was you, and now there is freedom.
Soon there will be vengeance.
That is certain.
Perhaps I deserved what came after the welcome as well.
It is a mistake I hope never to repeat.
No. I was prepared for combat, but I intended to strike subtly.
I thought so too. This world is full of fools, after all.
But in this instance, I was mistaken. Our visitors were not fools - they were bait.
Recruited. You could call it that. I intended to wage war on their god and the rest of its presumptive followers.
One part of it.
A smaller part than I had hoped.
It was the pale woman at the foot of the table - Orin the Red.
It was not the food I should have been wary of.
He invited me to the head of his table, as his guest of honour. I was wary, of course. If I had been in his position, the food would have been poisoned.
Ketheric proposed an alliance between Moonrise and Menzoberranzan. I admit, I was captivated by him.
He is usually in his laboratory, elbow-deep in offal, or clinging to his master's side. If he left Moonrise, his mission must be urgent.
We should ransack his chambers, and see what secrets he keeps for the great General.
No, we need to hit him smarter. This battle, like most, will be won or lost before the fighting begins.
Every chance once he is stripped of his power.
A true soul came to my city preaching a message of togetherness, accompanied by two novices.
Menzoberranzen is not fertile ground for such messages. I killed them, and hanged their bodies in my garden.
I would have picked prettier corpses if my intentions had been aesthetic. This was a warning against heresy.
I was not content with the warning though. I intended to wage war on their insolent god, and the rest of its followers.
Even as the flesh sagged and sloughed away from their eyeless skulls, their audacity infuriated me. I had to know where they came from.
And whoever sent them was counting on my curiosity overcoming my caution.
I would rather die than endure it again.
Indeed. A man you know all too well - General Ketheric Thorm.
The dead cough up their secrets just as well as the living.
All it took was a simple act of necromancy, and the corpses told me where I needed to strike - Moonrise Towers.
It is never safe to point out my shortcomings.
But in this instance, you are correct. Moonrise is the site of my greatest failure.
Despite Ketheric's best efforts, so are we. And we shall outlast the immortal general, and his tower.
But he had the upper hand when we first met. I was arrogant enough to believe I had the better of him.
As it turned out, to my shame, I was defeated without even drawing my weapon.
I came to Moonrise with a retinue of warriors and assassins - the best House Baenre had to offer.
I expected a battle, but found a fully-laden feast table, and a welcome befitting a house matron.
I recognise my flaws - pride is certainly among them.
In a manner of speaking, I did.
It was. But it has left a bitter taste.
And I do not need lectures on responsibility from somebody who does not know their own mind.
They were not my actions.
If you tire of their company, come to me. I may have other uses for you yet.
When you tire of their company, come to me. Tonight, you are mine.
You fought well. And so did these creatures, thanks to our leadership.
The githyanki should encourage relations between their soldiers. It is a proven tactic for morale.
You fight harder than ever now that you have a lover to protect from harm, Lae'zel.
Next time, tie them to the ground, and do not release them until you are both satisfied.
A few pointers, Lae'zel. I heard you and your lover locked in combat, but the test you set was not rigorous enough.
I am yours. Come to me.
You are exquisite.
I have never needed anyone. But I want you.
You give me courage.
What a wonderful distraction you are.
I could lose myself in you.
Enough. We still have a war to fight.
He is rather fond of himself. If he truly intends to be the saviour of Baldur's Gate, perhaps he has reason to be.
Even if I personally faced down the Army of the Absolute, and drove it from the city single-handedly, I would not be welcomed as a saviour.
No matter what I do, the people of Baldur's Gate will always see me as an enemy.
A faultless observation, Lae'zel. Are all githyanki so quick to come to the essential point?
How curious. The shadow curse has not touched this place.
Extinguish it? I intend to seize it. Power exists to be wielded.
We drow are sensitive to psionic power. And this place throbs with mental power such as I have never known.
Wake up, True Soul. We must talk.
They seek to promote peace between species through mutual understanding. Ha.
I watched over you as you slept, peaceful and silent, and I spoke to our god.
There is something missing in you, and I do not understand it.
I warn you - he is quite mad, but he knows the path to Moonrise better than anyone.
His minions will wait for you at the mountain pass, on the threshold of the shadow curse.
He was a drow once. Now he is an abomination, a victim of Lolth's cruelty.
This harp will summon him. Play it when you are in the shadows, and he will come to you and know that you are a friend.
But I can protect you. A wretched creature in my service can guide you through the curse.
The land around Moonrise is cursed. Travelling there will sap your strength and your sanity.
With difficulty - but I can help.
She will test you. If you fail, you will break; if your faith is strong, you will become something even more beautiful.
I know a way, yes. Soon, you will be in the Absolute's presence.
Wrong. The Absolute brought you to me, and now She will take you into Her presence at Moonrise.
The Absolute has spoken to you already, in whispers, but at Moonrise you will be in Her presence.
To gather our forces in this region. They're ill-disciplined - without a strong hand, they'll disperse.
I do not know - but I do know that She allowed me to spare you.
When you meet Her at Moonrise, She will show you Her design, and your part in it.
If She wanted you dead, I would not spare you. You live by Her grace.
Travel to Moonrise. We will meet again there, at the heart of the Absolute's power.
Good. I believe you.
She told me to decide your fate, to determine if you are worthy. If you are, I am to send you into Her embrace, at the seat of her power.
But then a miracle happened. As I took out my blade, Her voice returned to me... and She told me what I must do to purge myself of doubt.
And so I decided that you must die.
When the Absolute failed to answer me, I feared that you had somehow infected me with that same absence.
I asked Her why She had chosen you, made you one of Her faithful, when you are so clearly broken. Beautiful, but broken.
The Society of Brilliance! These preposterous fools love to meddle in Underdark affairs - they are most amusing.
On this plane, the story always ends the same way. Order collapses, and shadows take the light.
These people seem soldiers by their bearing. What say you, Lae'zel?
Ominous, yet austere. This place has its charms.
I do not want to be tolerated, I want to be feared. Don't you?
From the cult and the illithids? Of course. And then I suspect I want exactly what Gortash wants.
To be feared. Isn't that what you want?
When we have all three Netherstones and control the elder brain, all of Faer√ªn will have reason to fear us.
Yes they would. But I am the lesser of several evils, for now at least. I want more - don't you?
I agree. What matters is that they respect us... and fear us.
Was Baldur's Gate enjoying a golden age of prosperity and peace before Gortash rose to power? I think not.
This city is like a wild beast. It needs a strong hand to choke it into obedience.
Gortash may have that strength, but he chose the wrong allies to rule alongside him.
True. His mistake was choosing the wrong allies.
Ketheric was reliant on his god instead of his own strength, and Orin does not understand power and control. Only blood.
Perhaps you should rule in his place. Your choice of allies is exemplary, after all.
I am reluctant to share power, but if he is amenable to it, an alliance with Gortash may be beneficial.
Together, we can teach this city to fear us, and that is just the beginning.
Given his position in the city's power structure that may be easier said than done. I advocate for caution.
I was the Absolute's dagger. I remember every throat that it held me to, and every drop of blood it forced me to spill.
I take no responsibility for the lives I took. I did nothing in the Absolute's name - I was merely a weapon that it wielded.
The tadpole... the Absolute... they work together like a drug. I did not feel I was compelled to act against my will, I felt ecstatic to serve.
Every action seemed a deliberate choice - the best choice - even though I could no more have resisted its commands than flesh can resist decay.
The Absolute can make the impossible seem inevitable.
I do not blame him. It is not the sort of place servants or spawn should sully with their presence.
Devoured by the darkness. They should have retreated while they had the chance.
You do not need luck to survive, Astarion. Not when you have me.
Did you expect to survive Myrkul's wrath, little spawn?
And what do we do with rats, Lae'zel? We hang them by the tails, and burn their warrens.
There is no true authority in this city. The guards are more degenerate than the criminals.
Have you ever been afraid, Karlach? Truly afraid?
Better to shut off the carnal desires than indulge them. They are distractions.
You allowed that smith to meddle with your heart, Karlach, simply so you can be touched?
This place is foul. Drow would not tolerate rivers of waste flowing so close to their residences.
You have the aura of a third child about you.
In Menzoberranzan, after a house has two sons, every subsequent male-born child is slaughtered at birth, as it is useless, even for breeding.
Do you have elder siblings, wizard?
All I will say on the matter is that you were wise to lower your standards from the godly to the ghastly.
You have been protected from the worst of the Absolute's influence. Understanding what was done to me is beyond you.
You've been smiling like a fool of late, wizard. Explain yourself.
Our illithid warns us away from what lies beyond that gate, but perhaps it underestimates us.
The rashes and sores you may have contracted over your decades of philandering are not the kind of curse that concerns me.
The shadows have lingered here so long, the land itself is corroded. A most persistent curse.
If they have prevented your eyes and fangs from wandering to other necks, it must be a special bond indeed.
Would you ever consider sharing the gift of immortality with me, Astarion?
Are you a better man now that you are loved, Astarion? Did they mend your ways?
Hrmmph.
You would fit right in with them, Astarion.
Half the men of Menzoberranzan are pleasure-servants. Weaklings, whose beauty is their only redeeming quality.
Greater horrors await us in Baldur's Gate. Best sharpen your fangs.
Watch your tongue, spawn. I need the illithid alive - you are expendable.
Even rational minds like ours cannot reject such a powerful influence.
I have been told that I am special since my mother first held me in her arms. The burden of expectation.
Your family is a little too cut-throat, even for me, child of Murder. But we can certainly rule together.
We do not need to trust Viconia, we only need to know which side she will take in this conflict, and that is clear.
She will take our side because it best protects her interests.
Neither the Zhentarim or the Guild are capable of running this city as they should.
Once we have conquered the Absolute, perhaps we can turn our attention to dissolving the criminal elements of Baldur's Gate, and replacing them with our own candidates.
Hear me, wizard. You cannot go through with Elminster's ludicrous plan.
Destroying the Absolute before we fully understand it would be madness.
To serve the gods is always a choice, and to martyr oneself for them is insanity.
You are a wizard, are you not? Surely you have an obligation to learn about the world and all of its mysteries rather than destroying them.
I'm glad you see reason. To martyr oneself for the fickle gods is insanity.
You are welcome to explode wherever and whenever you please, as long as you do not destroy anything of value.
I, for one, will miss the shadow curse. For all the pain it caused us, it did at least obscure the incessant sun.
This place is wondrous. A shame it is not ours to command.
I must ask you something. First, let me make it clear that I do not object to the killing of Isobel, or the loss of Last Light.
Sometimes I think you are quite mad. Other times I think you still hold on to a slim fragment of your sanity.
I will be watching you - and watching for this 'butler' of yours as well.
We paid the price for your thrills when the shadows surrounded us. If you must kill for the pleasure of it, select your targets more carefully.
I would prefer if you informed me of your intentions before striking in future.
I prefer strategy to instincts and impulses.
I see. The end does justify the means. Be that as it may...
Your father - the Lord of Murder - offered you all of the powers of death and carnage. Powers that we will need before this fight is through.
And instead you have chosen to sever yourself from the legacy of blood that was your inheritance.
If she were here, Shadowheart would remind you that we are hardly trustworthy ourselves.
I was ready to rule by your side, Slayer. But you have given up a most glorious and dishonourable birthright. We are finished.
She has been exiled from the Underdark for more than a century. She would not have survived if she were not willing to fight.
You insult me. Viconia left the Underdark to rule a clergy of mournful waifs, and peddlers of secrets. I have far grander ambitions.
It is better to accept that, and to make sure she is ready to fight to the last.
Unnerving though it is, if we are to face an elder brain, we could have no better ally than an illithid.
The Emperor is the reason we have made it this far, and if the gith prince's suffering is the price of our survival, so be it.
It is sad to see how Jaheira has neglected her family. They should be prepared for the battle that is coming, or they may not survive it.
If any child of mine spoke of me as disrespectfully as Jaheira's offspring speak of her, their lives would be exceedingly short.
My mother taught me to talk, to walk, and then to kill. I still hope to thank her by teaching her how to die one day.
All things considered, my relationship with her may not be the best model to follow.
Gothic. Decadent. Vulgar. I can see this place had quite the influence on your tastes, Astarion.
Gothic. Decadent. Vulgar. This place clearly had quite the influence on Astarion's tastes.
I had thought Cazador little more than a decadent slave-driver and stalker of the night.
This is it. The end of everything - or our moment of triumph.
Patricide is often the first step toward greatness, but I hope Wyll does not regret sacrificing his infernal powers.
No matter how desperate the fight becomes, stay the course. We will not fail. We will dominate.
Myrkul, Bane, Bhaal, and now Shar? Are there any gods who do not want the Prism?
No matter - they will all be disappointed. Lord Ao the Overgod could not take it from us.
Bhaal should be begging me to join his ranks.
I was unsure of our alliance with the Sharrans - betraying Shadowheart seemed a steep price to pay - but I accept the wisdom of it now.
Despite my antipathy to Viconia, I am sure she will aid us when the time comes.
Two hundred years ago, she disgraced her family - the DeVirs - by refusing to obey a divine order from Lolth.
It was quite the scandal, and I was young enough that it left an impression on me.
I admire those who challenge authority, but Viconia fled from her troubles rather than facing them.
I do not mean to diminish her achievements entirely though.
You have seen a god reanimate the bones of his Chosen, you have seen an entity capable of commanding legions with a thought.
You have seen the fires of the Hells, and the devils who dwell there.
If you believe love is a greater power than all of that, you are stupider than I feared.
Vengeance is a bitter pill for kind souls. I pity Karlach that she could not savour Gortash's death.
Indeed. When my time comes, I will not go quietly.
For her sake, we should not. And besides, celebrations can come later - our fight is not over yet.
She will be ready to right when we need her, I am sure of it.
If the devil truly holds an artefact that can free Prince Orpheus, we cannot ignore it. Any ally who can aid us against the brain is worth having.
Even when the faithful abandon them, sacred places do not lose their power. Be on your guard.
The darkness here reminds me of home - so does the danger. Be on your guard.
Z'rell said we should begin our search at the Thorm Mausoleum. It is north of the House of Healing, deep in the shadows.
I would advise a thorough search of Balthazar's chambers at the tower before delving into the mausoleum. Any knowledge we can find may arm us for what is to come.
If we meet again, kill me quickly if you can. I prefer oblivion to enslavement.
No... worse than death. If I leave, if I am not protected from the Absolute's voice as you are, then it will take me again. Body, mind and soul.
If I leave, I die.
Lolth has discarded me, and the cult of the Absolute abused my mind, and stole my body. If you stand against them, you stand with me.
Spare me your sanctimony, druid. You kill to preserve your natural order, do you not? Or are the claws and fangs simply for show?
I have no quarrel with you.
It was the Absolute that directed my hand toward your grove - the same Absolute that I am sworn to destroy now that I am free of its influence.
Doubtful. Like everything else in these lands, its original purpose has been corrupted by the shadows.
Something lingers there. Something that inspires terror among those cultists unfortunate enough to have glimpsed it while patrolling the area.
They dare not enter. Naturally, anything that frightens them intrigues me. We should investigate.
Ketheric himself was entombed there for decades. An undying man, sealed in darkness with the bones of his ancestors.
I would have thought he'd seen enough of the place for several lifetimes, but he still visits on occasion.
You will realise, soon, how little you need her. Or you will die, mourning a loss that has no meaning.
She infests your notion of the weave, just as the Absolute's voice infested my thoughts.
She has made you believe that you need her. That is what the gods do. In truth, she is not so different to the Absolute.
Now stop sulking and practise your spellcraft. We have a city to save, and an elder brain to master.
It would have been a mercy - at least I'd have been spared this drivel.
If you have any strength left, bring it to the battlefield. You certainly do not have enough to share my bed anymore.
It is the perfect time for whatever was between us to die.
You rejected the extraordinary, and for what?
The only reason you ever lost control is because you resisted the truth - rejected the glory of your true self.
Bhaal gave you an opportunity to embrace your savage birthright, and to tame it.
The relationship between gods and mortals will always be one of subservience, but you could not hope for a finer master than Bhaal.
He gave you an opportunity to embrace your savage birthright and to tame it.
Without the promise of your blood, I fear you have lost part of your strength that you can never regain.
If you need a pat on the head and a scratch behind the ears, I am sure Minsc will provide. Boo has him well-trained.
Hope lives in the imagination. I prefer to deal in reality, and in our reality, Karlach is dying.
Talk to Jaheira if you wish to hear tales of heroic Bhaalspawn and their past victories. She likes filling peoples' heads with noble ideals.
I would prefer to cut your throat, and finish what Bhaal could not.
But you may still be effective, even in your diminished state, and we have precious few allies in this battle.
If it's congratulations you want, I am sure Karlach will provide. The language may be foul, but the feeling will be fair.
If you want mindless praise and affection, find Scratch. He will nuzzle your hand and follow at your heel no matter how disappointing you are.
I deal in reality, not idealism, so you will have to seek praise elsewhere.
I hope Elminster's message has not left you feeling dejected, wizard. It is better for you to be free of Mystra.
Now, return to your books. We have a city to save, and an elder brain to master.
Oh? Are you suddenly incapable of touching the weave? Do your spells fizzle before you can cast them? I think not.
You are Gale, Wizard of Waterdeep, and with or without Mystra, you are as great a practitioner of magic as anyone I have ever known.
There has never been a need to.
If you want empty platitudes and a rousing, gallant speech, young Wyll Ravengard may be able to provide it.
Perhaps a particle of sentimentality remains in Ketheric, and he mourns for his family. I do not know.
You cannot seriously believe that?
She is a fierce ally, and has survived great torments and challenges already. We would be fortunate to have her with us until the end.
I would like to be among them - I think there is much we could learn from one another.
The wizard? No.
It is pointless. In my experience, the moment they leave their libraries, wizards have the life expectancy of a gnome in a war.
Either the enemy recognises they are a threat, and kills them swiftly, or their curiosity leads them to combust while experimenting with the limits of magic.
Present company excluded, of course. I am sure you will live to a ripe old age.
Gale, however, is already in a state of suspended combustion thanks to that orb between his ribs.
I suspect it is only a matter of time before he goes up in smoke.
I will reserve my social graces for those who might live long enough to appreciate them.
Our wizard is already in a state of suspended combustion thanks to that orb between his ribs.
Don't sulk. I admire your mastery of the weave, but I have known many wizards.
Their mastery of the weave is commendable, but they are poor conversationalists.
In my experience, they do not usually live long enough to make the effort of befriending them worthwhile.
He is exceedingly self-righteous. Amusing, considering he bound himself to a devil.
Wyll doesn't just have blood and dirt on his hands, he has stains on his soul. Those last more than a lifetime.
It is as it should be. Purity of soul and deed will not help us to survive the Absolute.
I would rather be allied with a warlock than the spoiled son of a noble who has more experience with diplomats than devils.
I am not judging, I am making an observation.
The devil makes Wyll strong. What would he be without her?
