That fear was imposed on you. The fears that you have now are yours.
When bards sing of our victory against the Netherbrain, those who hear it will think the story is an exaggeration, or a work of the imagination.
Is this world truly your home now, or do you still dream of a life among your own people?
Only the fortunate and the bold are able to live the life they choose. I am happy for you.
You may try.
You earned their trust, their affection, and their loyalty. That is your strength, child.
Tell me - how goes your war against the tyrant queen?
You look well, Lae'zel.
You may be right, but I cannot help but wish we had tried. That is in the past though.
We can write our own stories now, and leave our mark on these Realms.
Free? What purpose does he have that does not involve his Master? He fears him, he hates him, he dreams of him - and he will either kill him, or die trying.
Astarion is no more free of Cazador than you or I are free of our tadpoles.
He will only be free when Cazador is dead. And that is as it should be.
When the time comes, we must hope that he does not only take Cazador's long life, but the power that has sustained him as well.
But Astarion is not only bound to his needs and desires, he is still bound to something more powerful - his Master.
I have encountered few githyanki in my life. Those that I did were raiders - they croaked out pleas for mercy in their alien tongue as they died.
Meeting Lae'zel makes me wish I knew more of their culture.
I did. She told me that she has nothing to teach that cannot be learned through observation of her prowess in combat.
Perhaps she is right - she certainly cuts a striking figure in battle. There is a precision to her ferocity that I admire.
To one who only sees the surface of things, perhaps. You should look deeper.
You should be. On those rare occasions when people have surprised me in the past, I received new scars to remember them by.
In spite of her youth, there is a patience and precision in Lae'zel's thoughts and actions that I admire.
I think I am beginning to.
So here we are. A gathering of allies at a cold campsite, with no servants to attend us, and few luxuries to enjoy.
We could have been conquerors... we could have ruled these Realms as gods.
Do you ever regret that we did not take control of the Netherbrain?
Do you think of all rulers as monsters? Conquest need not end in blood and ashes. You could have built a greater world than this.
I shall not dwell on the past though. The future is unwritten, and rich with possibilities.
True. But what better revenge could there be than enslaving the abomination that was the author of my torment.
Hmph. If your mind is still so rigid after all it has suffered, there is little point in trying to change it.
Regrets are of little value unless they are fuel for future victories.
Few mortals have stood against gods and monsters as we have and lived to tell the tale.
Those qualities will strengthen as she matures.
You do not need to thank me for speaking the truth.
It would be wise to return to him and pledge an oath of allegiance before he declares us enemies of the peace.
I did not expect to meet one still sworn to Lolth who would understand me.
If you sense my fear, be sure that she does too. It is her greatest weapon.
She had me in her clutches once before. Promise that you won't let it happen again.
Thank you. Together, we will survive her.
Against Orin? I have my doubts.
We need to watch over each other, now more than ever.
I am not intimidated, I am terrified. You should be too.
I doubt it. Her father is murder incarnate, and she is a devoted daughter. To please Bhaal she would butcher the world.
She has the scent of our blood, and she wil tease and toy until she tires of the hunt. Then she will obliterate us without a second thought.
Do not presume to know how I feel.
Her aim will be to erode our trust in one another. We cannot let that happen.
You see through my Minthara-mask, pretty little flesh-thing.
A joke. I am no more Orin than you are.
If she is watching - and she may well be - she will delight in seeing suspicion spread among us so quickly. We cannot let that happen.
If we kill every suspicious person in Baldur's Gate, we will have more blood on our hands than Bhaal.
Nervous? Don't be preposterous. I am on alert, as you should be too given who hunts us.
I have faced Orin before, and she left scars on me that will never heal. She will enjoy adding to them, and she can strike whenever she pleases.
She could be anywhere... could be anyone.
I do not often doubt myself, but surviving Orin took courage and strength I was not sure I had.
I could not have faced her without you.
You are trying to raise my spirits. I appreciate it, but any joy the sight of Orin's corpse brings me is but a speck of comforting shade.
There is little relief to be found from the heat of the storm we are caught in.
Orin could be anywhere... could be anyone.
Correct. I am glad that you see things as I do - no matter what victory we have won, we cannot afford to relax our guard.
I am not on edge, I am alert, as you should be too.
But I will never forgive him for handing me to Orin. For that, I hope Myrkul hollows out his bones, and lets them be dust.
I was like her once, when we first met, and before you ever knew me.
Oh, but I am. Given what we learned of her mother, I see how similar we truly are.
A madwoman, butchering prey in the name of a god who would discard me without a thought once I was no longer of use.
Bhaal, Lolth... the Absolute. They do not have followers - they only have victims, and they reward devotion with death.
It is only because of you that I did not meet the same fate as Orin. Lost to madness and blood.
If you had killed me when we first met, I would have been just one more casualty of your crusade against the Absolute.
And nobody would remember me.
Given what we learned of Orin's mother, that is painfully accurate.
We were both born of trauma, both raised by parents who protected us with one hand and tormented us with the other.
That was true, once. When you first knew me, I was no different to Orin.
As you wish. There is little use fretting over spilt blood.
I take no pleasure in his passing. Whatever faults he may have had, Ketheric was a great leader.
Of course. He ruled Moonrise for centuries. That in itself deserves respect.
Life was crueller to him than death. It is no great wonder that he found his strength in Myrkul.
I believe he was an honourable man, but the gods used him as their plaything. First, Shar and her sister, then the Three behind the Absolute.
I sympathise.
It is a sharp mind that feels sympathy for one who suffers unnecessarily, not a soft heart.
I saw strength in Ketheric that had been diluted by pain.
As are we, and if the coming battle breaks us, I hope that someone will mourn our passing despite the bodies we have left in our wake.
A meaningless question. If he had killed us, and conquered the Sword Coast, I would envy him.
As it is, he lost, and I pity him.
No more than you or I.
While the brain is still free, and we are still infected, we will never be safe.
But we can talk of this later. For now, let us be glad that we still draw breath. And that Orin does not.
Like a dream half-realised. Our fight is not done.
Hmmm. The weak and the elderly perhaps.
The young would be better used as a labour force than as a source of nutrition.
That is your gift to me, and we are bound together until it is done.
Perhaps longer, if you wish it.
While Orin lives, I fear we will not last long at all, whether together or apart. We must find her, and kill her.
You see a future for us once our enemies are dead? I am not so sure.
I hope so too.
It may become more - I hope that it does - but it may also become the cold ash that follows the flame. Or another story written in scars.
Whatever the case, it will be a short story if Orin has her way. We must find her, and kill her.
Indeed. We should make haste.
Sorry. Old habits.
I did not ask permission.
When we first met - before Moonrise - I intruded on your thoughts without hesitation, and took what I needed from your memories.
I would not do that again unless I had reason to think you were hiding something from me. And I do not.
I did not think we would ever share anything more than an uneasy alliance, born of our mutual enmity for the Absolute.
I was wrong. A deeper bond has grown between us.
I trust you.
But I would like to touch your thoughts again, now that my mind is my own. May I?
Of course. I do not hide anything from you.
Curiosity.
When the Absolute fell silent, I thought I would be alone. I expected to spend my days among surface-dwellers who knew nothing of my culture.
I do not disagree. But to turn them away would be wasteful.
If they are weak, they will die, whether it is on the road or in the defence of the city. And if they are strong, they will find a way to survive.
Yes. And if they work hard enough for long enough, the city might allow them to earn their freedom one day.
Perhaps you think it would be better for them to starve or be slaughtered here, while the citizens hide behind their walls?
The tadpole you harvested is not a curiosity to be pickled and studied - it is a weapon that can unlock the potential of our own parasites.
If you will not use it, give it to me.
All I ask is that you do not waste it.
I see the change in the shimmer of your skin, and hear it in the hum of your blood. You are evolving.
You absorbed a tadpole's essence to accomplish this change. Do you have more?
Free of the Absolute's influence, the tadpole is a boon. It has expanded my mind, and improved my body.
I am no longer simply its host - I am its mistress.
All I ask is that you do not waste them.
If you ever hesitate to indulge your illithid potential, remember that I will not.
Ink and paper are not as insidious as the voice of the Absolute, but they send out their commands all the same.
I did not expect you.
Is that so? I suppose it explains why they allowed a tyrannical servant of Bane to take control of their city.
Is that so? I suppose that is why they have allowed a tyrannical servant of Bane to take control of their city.
Truly, the citizens of Baldur's Gate are a model of shrewd wisdom that we should all hope to emulate.
Yes. I am surprised the house matrons of Menzoberranzan have not discovered the power of the printing press yet.
Paper spun from spider-silk, Everdark ink drawn from dragon scales, and nefarious lies dreamt in darkness.
To kill one's enemies with a well-rounded phrase... that is true power.
An excellent question.
I would use the Mouth to ensure the people did not trust one another. Suspicion creates doubt, and doubt creates dependency.
And they would know that they could depend on me. Feared, venerated, adored. I would be everything to them.
I was not suggesting they be allowed to roam free. They should be put to work - the city needs labourers, and fodder to protect it.
I am suggesting they be fed and sheltered, and that they work in return. Call it whatever you wish.
Perhaps it is why they will allow us to rule in his place when the time comes.
Then we are more alike than I realised. Even though you chose this life, you will always be an exile while your heart belongs in another home.
I have already returned... though there is little luxury there for me anymore, only war and madness.
One day, I may return to Menzoberranzan, as a conqueror or as a sacrifice. But my fight is elsewhere for now.
Tomorrow we return to the Underdark, and our campaign against my House continues.
Of course not. I was simply playing my part, and trying to have a little fun.
Your affection is the only thing that matters.
Then they are fools. You are the best of them, or I would not have chosen you.
It is the only thing.
Let us finish our socialising and be done.
I have hosted gatherings of House Matrons and High Priestesses who wanted nothing more than to murder one another before the night was done.
I have negotiated the handover of hostages and smiled politely while sensing a dagger at my back.
I thought I was equal to anything. But this is all so... pleasant. And I am not even sure anyone here likes me.
The great vampire lord. Tell me - where is the best feeding ground in Baldur's Gate?
Hmm. I expected too much meat and wine might cause the blood to curdle like day-old milk.
I wish you well, Lord Astarion.
Just remember, if you are ever tempted to taste my blood, you may enjoy the taste, but not the toxins.
Oh, and Astarion - the next time you throw one of your infamous masquerades, I would be delighted to attend.
Excellent. It will save me the effort of sneaking in under a false name. It is tiresome to masquerade before the ball even begins.
If you can not recognise my qualities, you can wear Cazador's title and squat in his palace for as long as you like.
You will always be a scared little spawn.
Of course. But next time, a formal invitation if you please.
I shall see you in the city.
A varied diet is indeed the key to a long life.
If the inhabitants taste anything like they smell, you have peculiar taste indeed.
Tomorrow we return to Baldur's Gate, and our campaign to control the city's undesirables continues.
This night shall be done sooner than any of us would like. I hope we meet again.
I always have strength enough for you. Do not make me wait long.
Tomorrow we return to Avernus, and our campaign against Zariel continues.
That is troubling. Just as great tapestries begin with a single stitch, the most treacherous plots begin with a few whispered words.
I fear you are engaged in a grand game of Lanceboard, young Wyll, and you are already four moves behind.
If I were causing trouble, surely your Flaming Fist would have paid me a visit in these last six months?
In fact, when I pass them in the street, they wish me 'good day' and 'good fortune'.
Do not forget, young Ravengard, that I too am one of the saviours of Baldur's Gate. I stood with you when the city was on its knees.
To peace and prosperity. You will make an excellent Grand Duke, Wyll Ravengard.
If the city should fall, I will be here to raise it again. I am many things, but I am not a fool.
While Baldur's Gate is my home, I would see it stronger than its neighbours, and I will do everything in my power to make it so.
I am wounded.
We do not need to trust one another. Just stay out of my way.
If that day ever comes, I look forward to seeing how much the wine and good living has dulled your blade.
Make sure it is the good one.
As you wish. I have business of my own to attend to, after all.
Yes, my love? Are you done talking to your friends? Can we leave?
I think not.
They may respect me or fear me, but I do not think they like me.
What makes me so? My quick wit? My cold heart? My cutting insights?
In truth, I have never enjoyed parties... although they do present the perfect opportunity for a poisoning.
You assume I am joking?
Taste my lips. They are already laced with toxins - none shall be spared tonight, not even you.
Now go - mingle, carouse, indulge.
We will need all of our strength.
There is more to you than I recognised at first, young Ravengard.
I thought you vainglorious, and saw your adventures on the frontiers as little more than an excuse to grow your legend.
Now you fight in the Hells, where there is little to be gained, and much to be lost.
And it is only your ascension to godhood that makes you so. As a mortal, you were scarcely fit to look at me.
Bah.
Do not tell the others, or I'll burn down the first Galerian temple I see.
There is no mark you could put upon me, or proclamation you could make against me, that would make my life more hazardous than it already is.
I have survived this much of my exile, but I have few friends left in this world. Or any other.
You are many things, Gale. The man who became a god, the Wizard of Waterdeep... but a keeper of secrets you are not.
I expect everyone will know of my affection for you by morning, but it does not matter. Tomorrow, I will be far from here.
I always thought you had a sharp mind - your misreading of me suggests otherwise.
Given where I tread, I would not survive if my heart were not as hard as my blades are sharp.
Now that Karlach and I are united against Zariel's legions, Avernus burns hotter than ever.
I fear there can be no victory in the war that has chosen us, but every moment we spend together is cause for celebration.
And every foe we vanquish makes me glad to be alive, for however many days remain.
Baldur's Gate needs fresh leadership, and I am only too happy to provide. I keep to the shadows, of course, for the sake of my complexion.
With our adventures behind me, it is good to engage with the intrigue of politics again.
Even the most cunning Baldurian conspirator would struggle to survive a tenday in Menzoberranzan.
They will learn from me, or they will bow to me.
An intriguing proposition. To harness the powers of the heavens as I once harnessed you...
I will think on it, but I make no promises.
We do not know yet what calibre of god you will prove to be.
I would no more allow a god to shape my destiny than I would a pigeon.
Naturally. A fledgling god is of little use where my plans are concerned.
I bow to nobody, wizard, and you should not expect me to. We defeated the Absolute together. We are equals.
Then we are fortunate there is nobody fitting that description here. My fortunes have only improved since the defeat of the Netherbrain.
Your godhood will have a much stronger chance of staying intact if you only smite those who do not smite back.
You are correct, no doubt. I have seen more terrors than wonders since we last met.
It is courageous, or it is foolish, but it is certainly not self-serving.
Then it is courage that drives you. And love.
Better to be a fool with a purpose than an idle politician. Better to be a devil-slayer than a Duke.
Everyone in these Realms is afraid of something. Wolves, sunlight, beasts, fiends, death... loneliness.
But those who fear themselves travel the most difficult road to find their courage. You have done so, Wyll.
Well, then you are a greater fool than I thought. There is no glory in the Hells.
But at least you have risen to a greater challenge than slaying goblins and bugbears.
You have become a better man than you were.
I will never understand why people thank one another for making honest observations.
But thank you for listening.
Baldur's Gate is her home now, thanks to you, and she cannot profit from a city in decline. She will see it flourish, and she will share in its prosperity.
Not by my estimation, but you do not need to concern yourself with that.
Yes, Wyll. I am a paragon of virtue. I volunteer at a local orphanage, and rehabilitate wounded owlbear cubs.
All so that the children and cubs alike can be moulded to my purpose, raised in my image, and made willing to die in my name.
Heh heh heh.
And you have no sense of humour.
Dekarios the divine graces us with his presence. I hope you do not expect me to bow or utter a prayer in your honour.
The only thing more insufferable than a wizard is a god.
Better gods than you have tried.
I am glad to hear that smiting is in your divine repertoire though. I feared you would be a dull kind of god.
There is the wizard I remember. Finding the dreariness in divinity.
It is good to see you, Gale.
You are correct, but our differences are unimportant when it comes to this matter.
Neither of us can profit from a city in decline. We will see it flourish, and we will share in its prosperity.
Just as I have the best interests of Baldur's Gate at heart, so does Mizora.
Of course she does.
Have you?
Then your adventuring days are not behind you. That is good. You are young yet, and these Realms are wide and full of wonder.
Perhaps. But do not be surprised if you hear the howl of the wolves one night, or see a sign flashing across the stars, and leave your hearth behind.
I do not think your adventuring days are behind you.
Tranquility will always be waiting, at the end of your journey. Wherever it takes you.
Young Ravengard. My sources tell me you have returned to your former career - terrorising the Frontiers.
Can you ever be sure though? How many of the monsters you kill are simply defending their way of life from those your blade protects?
I doubt those you turn your blade against would agree.
The devil is a subtle creature. She will do as she always has - select victims that resemble monsters, and use your talents to dispose of them.
Then you are wiser than I thought.
Well met, young Ravengard. May your blade strike true more often than not.
Impressive. She has taught you to deceive yourself so adeptly that perhaps she does not need to direct you at all.
You could choose to lay down your blade, to lay down your life, to give up your soul. That you do not tells me which life matters most to you.
Your own.
Well met, young Ravengard. I do not think our paths shall cross again.
I did not expect you of all people to be a devil's lapdog for the rest of your days.
I am sure that being slain by a heroic blade is of great comfort to your victims.
I have been both victim and monster. Whichever you saw me as, if your turned your blade on me, there are still those who would grieve my passing.
And I would bleed like any other.
I was taught that any man who spoke out of line, or above his lowly station, should be punished. I called that justice.
I do not think there is such a thing as justice anymore, and I do not find my comfort at either end of a blade.
Any who survive the torments of the gods deserve peace. Most never find it.
Shar inflicted such misery on you. Most would find it unbearable, but you have shown resilience.
Fresh from the farm, Jenevelle? It is good to see you.
I will have a palace soon enough, and when I do, I shall make you my jester.
Why not leave?
A word of advice? If there are those who would be hurt by your departure, do not slip away without saying goodbye.
They may be willing to follow and leave their world for you.
And if not... good riddance.
Which sewer did you crawl out of to join us here today, spawn?
Hmph. I am surprised you have survived there so long. Your face shines like a sickly beacon even in this light.
Oh, but I wish I could see it. You must spend your nights cursing your cowardice, and wondering what might have been.
Cazador really did teach you to ignore the stars in favour of your gutter.
Yes - my life is rich. A night without an assassin is a dull night indeed.
I think we're done here.
In this world, the two roles go hand in hand more often than not.
Dawn will be breaking soon. I need to guard my complexion... you need to guard your life.
Cazador sends his regards.
Ha - of course not. I am teasing you.
Then it would fit well with that ludicrous hairstyle you're so fond of.
Ha. Do not do anything that you would regret - I am, how do you say, pulling your limb.
If I ever meet that ancient fop, Cazador, I will reduce him to dust.
If I do you that service, I will expect something in return.
Where else but the Hells?
The city, of course. The site of our triumph.
My homecoming has begun.
Grotesque.
Oh, but one more thing.
When we first met, I could not have chosen that future. I could choose nothing.
Call yourself a slayer of monsters and be proud, for that is what you are.
I have seen you without a smile. It is a poor sight indeed.
Exquisite.
Wizard.
Human.
Your tressym is called Tara and she dislikes your beard. She is wrong - it is a fine beard. Dashing, even.
You enjoy travel and adventure, but miss Waterdeep whenever you are away. This is because your mind is restless, and can only find peace in familiar places.
Your ambition is not cruel, but you fear that if you indulge it, you will lose yourself in the mysteries of the Weave and unravel the world.
You are afraid of so many things, and it is that fear that keeps you true to yourself.
I know a great deal about you, Gale Dekarios. And that is precisely why I know how enjoyable it is to tease and befuddle you.
And you're still the same charming blend of pompous and naive. It is good that there are some constants in these maddening Realms.
Do not tell the others, or I'll clip your pussycat's wings.
You are many things Gale: the Wizard of Waterdeep, a man who has touched divinity, and the owner of a rather dashing beard.
But a keeper of secrets you are not.
Do not tell the others, or I'll set fire to your library.
Hmph.
Is that the smell of brimstone I detect, young Ravengard?
Of course. And to ensure I do not break protocol... should I refer to the lady Mizora as your Grand Duchess?
Of course. The city's prodigal son, returned as a saviour, and yoked to a devil - it is such a perfect satire, who could help but laugh?
Oh, but I have upset you.
Baldur's Gate doesn't have an aristocracy. Your Council of Four is a rogues gallery of merchants, politicians and adventurers.
And then of course there's your lady Mizora, to make a Council of Five.
Poor Wyll. What does the devil ask of you?
Of course. On this occasion, you need not even earn it, my sweet.
We will spend the rest of our lives together. Go, be with the others.
We - and they - need not adjust. We need only endure until we can claim the position we deserve.
We undid the Grand Design, and saved Baldur's Gate from annihilation.
I am still establishing a foothold in Baldur's Gate, but soon I will have strength enough to aid you.
When that is the case, I will gladly come to Avernus to fight by your side once again.
I have a war of my own to fight, against my mother and her people, and there is every chance I will not survive it.
But if I do, I will gladly bring my strength to Avernus to fight by your side again.
You are most welcome.
If the tadpoles still allowed us to share ourselves, I could show you.
Even then, you may not understand. As it is, you never will, because there are no words in my language or yours to explain such mysteries of the heart.
Helping an ally is its own reward. But I can think of few greater challenges than battling across the Hells.
Besides, what else would you have me do? Lay down my weapons and spend my last centuries growing plump? I think not.
You must.
I am glad to see you, Karlach. Your heart can survive the Hells, but I feared your spirit would not.
I have no doubt, but you need not fight alone.
How is the view from the Upper City?
How could it not with you to guide the reconstruction?
It is not only dukes and partriars who are doing their part though. I am helping too, in my own way.
Given your position, there are certain things that must go unsaid, but let us just say I do what you cannot to keep the city strong.
By toxin, blade or word, I weed out the weak and the untrustworthy. You may not like my methods, but our goals align.
I do not have a 'spot', I have a network. Our eyes see a city that needs help from the top and the bottom.
We can help, but we need your people to stay out of our way.
It is good to see you, Jenevelle. How do your parents fare?
To endure the agonies Shar inflicted on them for so long shows resilience. They deserve peace.
What is 'normal'? You and I were born to do extraordinary things - we have challenged the gods and live to tell of it.
Young Ravengard. An honour as always.
I am glad you recognised the benefits of that approach. If he proves troublesome, we can always kill him later, when his guard is down.
Listen, worm.
Even as the elder brain tears at the foundations of the city, he stands strong, and looks for solutions.
I would have thought this entire conspiracy of gods and monsters to be impossible if I had not seen it for myself.
But Baldur's Gate is a mere bauble. We have the chance to seize something much greater. Surely you see it?
What I propose is nigh on impossible, but if anyone can succeed, it is us. We have the Prism, and we have the courage to slay gods.
Then you misunderstand me.
I expected you would be, but know this...
It is as if you read my mind. Perhaps you did.
I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Now I know that those memories are lies.
She is the one who brought me to Moonrise, and into the presence of her so-called god - the Absolute.
If there is a way to turn this design toward slaughter rather than control, she will take it.
She is fierce, vicious, and cruel. In those respects, we are alike - but she is dangerously unpredictable.
And for that I am sorry. I will commit all future atrocities for my own gain - and yours, should we stand together.
Orin was by my side. She told me that god had chosen me to be a True Soul. Blessed and adored.
It was more of an idea than an entity. Pure love. Total power.
We may fail, but we must try.
When I first visited Moonrise, I stood before the Absolute in awe.
Patience. If we do not prepare, Baldur's Gate will be our tomb.
First we take the Netherstones, then the brain, then the world.
Those who kill without motive cannot be trusted. I would not like to wake with your knife at my throat, and never understand the reason why.
That troubles me.
I am satisfied.
A wise ploy, and it was successful, to an extent. We did not find a cure, but we found our purpose.
I jest, but it is as good a reason as any. I have done much more foolish things to win the respect of far inferior people.
I'm flattered. Will you be bringing dead rats and birds to my tent now that we share a camp?
So I ask again - why kill the inhabitants of the Grove?
I don't care about them, I care about you.
There is yet one thing about you that troubles me, though. Something I need you to explain.
We are bound, then, to travel together, even if we do not yet agree on our ultimate purpose.
You are not stupid. When we reach Baldur's Gate and face the other Chosen, you will see that my way is the right one.
There is violence in your future regardless. With me, you can at least be sure the violence will lead to glory.
Nothing worthwhile ever came without loss. But together we have the strength to decide who loses. And to make sure it is not us.
We have a purpose and a bond. By my oath, I will fight with you while that purpose holds.
And then we will need no gods. We will be their equal. We will be Absolute.
But if we are wise, it will be our dominion.
Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
He favours her, and she is one of the founders of this insane cult.
I would prefer to put my faith in your strength than the favour of your god. After all, it is Orin and this grand deception that he chose - not you.
You killed the dead man. I'm impressed.
Hmph. It is better to kill for it.
These Harpers of yours. Would they die for you?
An exile from Lolth, much like myself. There is no love for her in the Underdark.
This place has been used to make slaves of those who should be masters.
Whatever experiments Balthazar performed here, I fear he made more than thralls and ghouls.

You're the friendliest face so far.

What happened to the person I fell for? You've changed, and not for the better.

As you worship Sel√ªne, I assume you know of her twin?

... yes. I am honoured with her blessing.

Honestly? I think self-reflection may be the enemy just now. I can't afford to lose my nerve. Safer to just not think, and keep forging ahead.
Let's just stay shoulder to shoulder, and see this through.
High Hall. There's nowhere else to go... This is where it all ends, my love.
High Hall. There's nowhere else to go... This is where it all ends.

Lae'zel has a dangerous look in her eyes - let's just hope she reserves those impulses for any common foes.

I know. I can scarcely believe it's real, but I saw it with my own eyes, felt the polished stone walls raised in Lady Shar's honour...

Mmm, yes. Shy is indeed not a word I'd reach for, when it comes to her. I'm glad the city has you as a steadying influence - just don't solve all its problems, or I'll be short of new recruits.

I might need a few more of those, before the sun threatens to rise.
Hmm. I might have to call on you to trouble me again, before the night runs its course.
I won't forget that in a hurry - which is truly saying something, coming from me.
I can sympathise, truly.
I suppose you may.

Not in the slightest, no. But I am glad to hear it, nonetheless.

In all likelihood, it will be... but we mustn't let that stop us.
Honestly? So have I.
I suppose it can't be easy making friends amongst the gods, being the pantheon's newest arrival.
I was starting to wonder if you'd show up.
So modest. You and I both know your visage is a mark of pride - it denotes fearlessness, tenacity, a capacity for self-sacrifice that would make most hearts quake.
I have little doubt. But you can give your sword arm a rest - tonight is for celebrating.
Nobility suits you. I've been sure to keep some discreet eyes on your progress - their reports have been very complimentary.
So I have heard - just be sure to keep it far from Lady Shar's holy work. Even the sharpest blade can be dulled against her power.
And suits the populace, I daresay. They've probably had their fill of butchered corpses in the streets.
Perish the thought. You are right to look the part - I know the importance of appearances in maintaining your grasp of power all too well.
I think we both know the darkness is far superior anyway. Besides, the flicker of candlelight truly brings out your cheekbones.
Well, you pull it off admirably, I must admit. I'm sure you'll find plenty who'll fawn at the idea of a romantic fugitive.
You may very well be right. Perhaps you'll become the subject of books in years to come, rather than the avid consumer of them.
I'm glad you managed to pull yourself away from your leatherbound harem then.
How... descriptive of you. But I suppose that counts as thriving, by your yardstick.
Coming from you, that's high praise. The continent ought to be flattered.

And at the risk of sounding boastful, I think we have plenty to celebrate; Lady Shar's entire church prospers. The Absolute washed the Sword Coast with blood and tears - it is now fertile ground for her message to flourish.
Oh, do not fear them - there's no point in fearing the inevitable.
Intriguing. Yet I hope your ambitions don't grow so great that we find ourselves at odds. I would hate for you to force my hand for the sake of Lady Shar's interests.
Understandable. But rest assured that your secret is safe with me. Lady Shar respects those who live in the shadows.
Can you blame them? It must be like meeting their literary hero - or anti-hero, I suppose.
I have little doubt. Only the strongest of hearts could endure such challenges and maintain even a sliver of your good cheer.
Overawed, of course... but I have scarce time to saviour the majesty of Lady Shar's domain - there is yet work to be done, in her name.
Almost as busy as I am - such rapid growth creates a good deal of work for a quartermaster. So many lost souls, in need of dark cloaks... she has risen to the occasion though, as I knew she would.
A future in which she was discarded, where the reward for her service and sacrifice was to groom her own replacement?
You did, and I'll be forever grateful. I'll keep Lady Shar's followers away from your nascent church for as long as I can... give you a sporting chance.
Let's keep that our special secret. I have a reputation to maintain, you know.
You're lucky none of my followers are around to witness this. Come here...
What, a show of sincere affection...?
Like a rare vintage... bittersweet to taste so infrequently, yet always worth the wait.
I'd like to think I'm cunning enough to get away with it. Come here to me...
Now, tell me all. What have you been doing with yourself this past while?
At least let's enjoy tonight, then I can leave you be once more. In time, you will feel the old yearning again, and darken my door.
You didn't seem to be of that mind when we last slipped away together. You couldn't get enough of me, as I recall.
But let's not grow maudlin - this is a celebration. Tell me what you've been doing with yourself.
I jest. You would think I'd be accustomed to loss, yet it stings all the same. Lady Shar may keep me occupied, but there is always a place in my heart and mind for you.
I don't know if that's strictly true... I think I saw just about every inch of you, when I last slipped away from my duties...
... And tonight, of all nights, was made for indulgence.
But don't worry. I'm sure you'll find there's still plenty to like, if you care to indulge...
Nor are you the same person who fell for me. Time can be unkind to hearts in that sense, especially if you fear change.
Nor are you the same woman who fell for me. Time can be unkind to hearts in that sense, especially if you fear change.
Nor are you the same man who fell for me. Time can be unkind to hearts in that sense, especially if you fear change.
We would have been able to claim just enough of each other's hearts in order for it to hurt. Better to indulge ourselves fully whenever fate allows, than to live in compromise...
A pity, yes... but also for the best, perhaps. It would have pained me to have you close, but not be able to dedicate myself to you in every waking moment.
You should see how they flock to us. We spread like the night sky chasing the sun below the horizon.
Broken hearts, shaken faiths, refugees without homes, former cultists without purpose... they can all become the Nightsinger's children, with the right nudge.

Very apt choice of words. But it doesn't just go for me; Lady Shar's entire church prospers. The Absolute washed the Sword Coast with blood and tears - it is now fertile ground for her message to flourish.
Her entire church prospers. The Absolute washed the Sword Coast with blood and tears - it is now fertile ground for her message to flourish.

You did, and I'll be forever grateful. Perhaps one day, you may open your eyes to her wisdom yourself... but even if you do not, I shall make sure that the sharp edge of her spreading gospel does not trouble you.
What transpired was the Dark Lady's will. If time rolled back, I would do the same thing all over again, without hesitation... yet I am not without sympathy.
You have worshippers of your own, Gale. Are you really in a position to judge? I'd have expected the god of ambition to understand that you must do whatever it takes.
If those people didn't come to me, who knows where they'd end up? Lady Shar provides food, shelter, training, purpose... and the wisdom  that one day, their pain will no longer matter.
I came to see her as an adversary, an obstacle, but what recourse did she have? What did she see when she looked at me?
I shouldn't... but from time to time, yes. Holding the office she once held, standing within the shadow of Lady Shar herself... It complicates my feelings towards her.
Simplicity is a luxury that's drifted out of my reach, I'm afraid. But at least for tonight, I can have a taste of how it used to be.

All-consuming. Endless decisions to make, underlings jockeying for your attention, threats from the outside, threats from the inside... there's times I miss when it was just our little group against the odds.
Would that I could. But this is my life now. Lady Shar must come first - always.
And should one thing lead to another, well... we all deserve to be wicked, now and again.
I've got my own private wine cellar now - I'll keep a special vintage aside for your visit.
Oh you're far too cunning to fall for that. Consider Lady Shar's cloister your safe sanctuary, for as long as it answers to me.
But don't be such a stranger either, in future. You know where to find me - I can always make some time for an old friend. One of the privileges of being in charge.

But don't be such a stranger either, in future. Should Withers grant you leave from Avernus, you'll know where to find me - I can always make some time for an old friend. One of the privileges of being in charge.
I suppose you'll be keen to do the rounds, with so many old acquaintances gathered. Do not let me hoard your time.
I suppose you'll be keen to do the rounds, with your time here being so short. Do not let me hoard your attention.
But no matter - I'm quite content to let her ranks of minions dwindle against the edge of your blade.
You would think Vlaakith would understand by now that it would take more than a few cutthroats to best you.
No interest in a little respite then? I won't claim to be surprised - you never struck me as the sort to rest on her laurels, Lae'zel.
Ooh, you utter tease. I suppose I, of all people, can't begrudge you your secrets.
You've been busy! Careful you don't pull a muscle - I'm not there to nurse you back to health any more.
I won't pretend I'm not a little jealous. Lady Shar is a demanding mistress - as is her right to be - but a little calm and solitude would be a tonic.
Well I'd wish you luck, but my lady may not appreciate me encouraging the competition.
Apart from give closure to a former lover, perhaps? Don't worry - I'm not upset. Lady Shar would likely have prised us away from each other even if you had remained.
But enough of that for now - I won't have it said that I'm not capable of enjoying a fine night with good company. Tell me what you've been doing.
Sorry. Every gathering is an opportunity when you're doing the Dark Lady's work.
They have already been tempered by loss. They were meant to become her instruments.
Everyone is exploited. Lowest gutter to highest throne, there's always someone above you pulling the strings. If you think otherwise, you aren't looking hard enough.
Trust me, I'll keep up.
I... I don't know. Lady Shar expects me to act without question... but I need to think. I need to be sure this is what I want.
This place is quite something. I just hope it doesn't spring a leak.
Karlach has offered to take on the duty. She doesn't have much time left, so there's a certain logic in leaving this to her. A somewhat callous logic, mind you.
Karlach has offered to take on the duty. She doesn't have much time left, so there's a certain logic in leaving this to her. The Dark Lady would approve, I'm sure.
If... if you're sure. This is not a decision to make in haste, but you have my support, either way.
Very well. Let's do all we can to help her.
I see... then I hope she understands. But I trust your judgement.
Whatever you choose to do, you can count on my support.
I understand your determination. But we still need a decision.
If you think that's for the best... but I just hope the Emperor doesn't betray our trust.
Very well. Whatever happens, I shall stand by you.
That's Orin dealt with - good riddance. Now that we have her Netherstone, we're one big step closer to finishing this, once and for all.
This isn't over yet - we need to pursue Ketheric Thorm.
Just our luck to find an inn, only for it to be burning to the ground.
You... you sacrificed your own father? I hope freedom from the pact was worth it.
Wyll sacrificed his own father to be free of the pact. Remarkable resolve, if you can harden your heart. The Nightsinger would approve.
Wyll sacrificed his own father... I hope freedom from the pact is worth it to him.
An infestation of vampire spawn - that's just about the last thing I wanted to wake up to. We thwarted their efforts to seize Astarion, at least.
This place seems ancient. It must predate everything on the surface. I wonder what it was like in its heyday.
We can't just let Orin take one of our own - even if it's Lae'zel. We have to rescue her... or kill Gortash in order to win her freedom.
I'll never be able to look at a butcher shop again after this place. But at least we were afforded a soft landing.
Defying a goddess, Gale? Well, they do say imitation is a form of flattery. I just hope you know what you're doing.
Defying a goddess, Gale? Bold, but Mystra was never worthy of your love.
So Cazador wishes to ascend at your expense? Somehow, I doubt you intend to accept that meekly.
You sacrificed your own father, Wyll? Not a step that many could take, but the Nightsinger would appreciate your resolve, I think.
We need to make a decision - if anyone's to become a mind flayer, perhaps it should be Karlach. She's doomed either way.
The shadows are losing their grip on these lands - Shar can indeed be thwarted. Comforting to know.
Lady Shar's power will soon fade from these lands, but it is a price that had to be paid, so that the traitor Ketheric Thorm could face justice at last.
So, only a mind flayer can wield the stones, from what the Emperor said. And not a part-illithid either - the full-blown thing.
So, only a mind flayer can wield the stones, from what the Emperor said.
What do you think?
If you say so. But we still need a decision.
So, the githyanki have no cure for our condition - unless you count death as a cure. I won't pretend to be surprised.
So, you're free from your hunger, free from any lingering fear of the sun... but all those lives you sacrificed, Astarion. I'm not sure I'll forget their final screams any time soon.
'Vampire Ascendant'. A fine prize, Astarion, paid for with a sea of blood. I'm glad to know I have an ally who understands the value of sacrifice - congratulations.
Gale defied Mystra herself. Good - not every goddess is deserving of such love. I would know.
I don't know how exactly Orin managed to spirit away someone as big as Halsin, but we have to get him back - either via a rescue, or Gortash's death.
Karlach... you must have a lot to think about, just now. If you need time to yourself, take it.
Poor Karlach. All this way, just to be faced with a dead end - literally. I can't imagine how she feels.
What happened to that magical item, Gale...?
This place makes my skin crawl. Don't take anything for granted in here.
Gale's back on his feet - good. We've got enough problems as it is without him dead as well.
Minsc - he seemed to believe that doppelganger was truly Jaheira. A sure sign he's being manipulated.
I know you have your personal demons to contend with... but if I didn't make it clear before, I think you can beat this. Just don't give in, and seek help if you need it.
A cruel end. I wouldn't have wished that for Zevlor, no matter his failings.
We're in decidedly unfamiliar territory now - keep up the pressure, and stay alert. We need to find Thorm.
Astarion. You seem remarkably hale and hearty, in spite of all we're facing. The itinerant lifestyle must suit you.
An imposter in our ranks... if this is true, it could be anyone. You, me... well, not me - I know who I am.
Perhaps we shouldn't take Gortash's word for granted... but if he speaks the truth, we need to be careful. Orin could have eyes and ears on us right now.
That temper of yours is a sight to behold. You'll need to be careful, or your rage will burn right through you.
Karlach's temper is a sight to behold. She'll need to be careful, or that rage will burn her right out.
So Cazador wishes to ascend at Astarion's expense? Somehow I can't see our fanged friend accepting that meekly.
I never thought I'd see the Gauntlet of Shar for myself. In fact, part of me wondered if it was actually real.
The Orphic Hammer is ours - which means we could free Orpheus, if we wish.
I'm sorry that happened to you, Wyll - that bat-winged slattern deserves to meet the business end of a poo-scraper.
No matter. We've dealt with every other oddity thrown at us lately - we can handle this one too.
Now, as for this 'Raphael'...
He knows our secret, he claims he can help... what do you make of him?
Oh you were tempted, were you? Interesting.
What grabbed you, exactly? His parlour tricks? His manners? The lavish spread, even?
You must have found something alluring, to overlook the fact he was a devil.
You know, failing to make a decision is the same as making a decision...
... except you decide blindly.
My point is that Raphael was stirring the pot - trying to unsettle us.
Hmm. Or is it? Suddenly I'm not so sure...
... isn't it terrible when someone causes you to doubt yourself?
Your opinions are easily swayed. Should I wait for them to change again?
Perhaps you're right. Perhaps a devil has our best interests at heart and wants nothing in return.
We could throw ourselves at his feet - be they cloven or otherwise. Or perhaps we shouldn't.
Your gullibility would be endearing, if it didn't lead us into danger.
Bravo - you had me worried for a moment.
Clearly. And do you know what? I think that's just what that devil intended.
I assume you are joking.
Actually... yes, you're right. Very intuitive. Clearly the devil was trying to sow doubt among us.
He's clever. My order uses the same tactic when dealing with enemies of Shar.
I know people who work much like our new acquaintance does.
You don't need a scourge or a rack to break people. Fear and self-doubt are sufficient.
When actual pain comes, the victim's already done the heavy lifting for their torturer.
I've heard you can't get blood from a stone, but apparently you can get a wizard from one. Gale seems interesting.
The Netherbrain's lair must be close. This could all be over very soon, one way or another...
This place reeks of madness and murder - I can almost feel it in the rotten air.
Astarion's an interesting find. Let's hope any future acquaintances don't hold a blade to your throat by way of introduction.
But if it's any consolation, the new look is rather rugged...
The Underdark... as if we didn't face enough dangers back up on the surface.
So, a deal's been struck with Raphael at least. He certainly drew out his sales pitch for long enough.
I hope Mizora flies into the blades of a windmill for what she did to Wyll... though I must admit the new look is a little dashing...
So Astarion didn't fulfil his master's ambitions for himself. At least that means he's his own man... though I'm a little surprised he didn't covet those powers.
Minthara with child... Somehow I can't picture her sitting around the campfire, knitting baby booties...
Boo seems like a worthy addition to our group. His pet, Minsc, may prove useful also.
Shar's power still grips this land. A shame we could not banish it - it would have felt good to spite her.
This land remains cloaked by Lady Shar's power - good. A shame it cost us Halsin as a travelling companion though. He may have been misguided, but I liked looking at him.
That's the last of Raphael. I'll be glad to no longer have to suffer his smug face.
Not the cheeriest of inns, this place. But I suppose the mortal peril lurking just past the firelight is liable to put a dampener on the mood.
Minsc is dead, Jaheria is gone... We've lost ourselves some powerful allies, I fear. Let's just hope we still have enough strength to see this through.
Karlach... that was a decidedly mixed blessing you received. My sympathies... but at least you can seek comfort now.
Poor Karlach. She can finally seek out the touch of another... only to be told she might not have much time left.
The cr√®che... it's nothing but rubble and ashes now. We should put some distance between ourselves and this mess, before any githyanki come investigating.
That drow, Nere, is going to be on his last gasp unless someone digs him out. Though not necessarily our concern, of course.
It seems like Wyll and Karlach will play nice from now on. Saves us having to pick sides.
We need to make a decision - and you becoming a mind flayer seems like the least-worst option, unfortunately.
Most would think us mad for wandering right into the middle of a goblin war clan... I suppose that goes to demonstrate just how desperate we are.
So Gale just consumes magical items like I do wine? We truly are a group apart...
Nevertheless, as quirks go, that's a new one for me.
I just hope he's able to keep his hunger in check.
Gortash is no more - and he was kind enough to bequeath his Netherstone to us. We might yet manage to pull this off.
So Lorroakan covets Dame Aylin? He'll live to regret that, once we inform her.
I think I've had my fill of underwater misadventures. Let's get back to the surface world before any more perils seek us out.
I thought this camp was supposed to be our safe haven - not quite so when we wake up to dead tiefling bards. I may have difficulty sleeping for a while...
We need to keep pressing forward. The day isn't won until Ketheric Thorm has breathed his last.
In fact, none of us can. That thing is shielding us, somehow. I don't want to know what happens if we lose it.
I'll wager they'll thank you with a blade through the heart. You're tainted in their eyes, same as me. And your best chance is to stay close to the artefact.
Agreed. There's not much we can do but press forward.
I only know what I know... I was ordered to retrieve it, and that's what I intend to do. The rest is immaterial to me.
A problem for another time. Hopefully we'll no longer be in need of protection by the time my mission draws to an end.
Things won't be the same, without Astarion. At least he got to enjoy his moment of triumph... before we betrayed him.
You accepted Bhaal, after everything we've been through? I can only hope this is part of some clever scheme I'm not privy to. Otherwise you might as well have stayed with the Absolute.
Damn. I was hoping my imagination had gotten the better of me, but this must be something more.
It seems like we can't escape this mess, in the waking world or otherwise.
Don't play coy. It happened to you as well, didn't it? It's all over your face.
We shouldn't have allowed the likes of Aradin to get the drop on us. Better be careful in future.
It seems like Cazador used Astarion's flesh not as a canvas, but as a contract. We haven't heard the last of this, I'll wager.
Baldur's Gate... you know, I never quite believed I'd actually make it back. Wasn't until we got within reach of Wyrm's Crossing that it felt real.
I suppose I am. Though the chance to savour the moment might be brief, given all that still lies ahead of us.
I may have to rely on your local knowledge, to plug the gaps in my own mind. Hopefully I'll remember more than I expect to.
I suppose it is. Though the chance to savour the moment might be brief, given all that still lies ahead of us.
Blessings from afar...? Perhaps Mystra is more invested in you than it seems, Gale.
I had another dream - which I suppose means you did as well.
Whoever's reaching out to us truly does seem opposed to the Absolute - but wants us to embrace the tadpole? Venture right into the heart of the cult?
Perhaps we truly have a secret protector - or we're walking into a trap.
You'd think I'd have more sympathy for someone trapped in a pod, but perhaps we should have left Mizora where we found her.
So Cazador saw fit to carve his ambitions right into your flesh, Astarion. If I was you, I'd return the favour with interest.
That face-thief Orin's made off with Gale. We'll need to rescue him... unless we actually intend to kill Gortash for her.
It seems the githyanki are keen to reclaim the artefact I carry. I can't afford that to happen.
It seems you have made up with Mystra, Gale. Congratulations - though I don't see any such reconciliation between myself and Shar any time soon...
It seems your fellow githyanki are keen to reclaim the artefact I carry. I can't afford that to happen.
Feels like we're nearly at the end, one way or the other...
So it's the Blade of Avernus now, Wyll? I suppose that's a new sort of frontier.
So Wyll's the Blade of Avernus now? I suppose that's a new sort of frontier for him.
This place is like a glimpse into the future - no need to raise an army when you can just build one.
Minthara is in Orin's clutches. Either we try to mount a rescue, or pay for her release with Gortash's life.
The Shadowfell... this is Lady Shar's power in its purest form. Nothing can resist her will here.
So that's how you win Mystra's forgiveness - self-sacrifice? I'm sorry, Gale. That can't be what you wanted to hear.
This is it... where I was raised, trained... hells, it's strange to be back.
Our new friend with the myriad limbs seems to know this route well. I just hope we can keep the ruse up once we reach our destination...
It doesn't seem so long ago that Minthara would have sought to kill us, and now we've welcomed her along. We're nothing if not magnanimous.
It seems Gale has made amends with Mystra. Good for him - though I don't see any such reconciliation between myself and Shar any time soon...
It seems Gale has made amends with Mystra. Good for him - though his choice of goddesses leaves something to be desired...
Moonrise Towers... if this is indeed the very centre of the Absolute's schemes, then the source of our problem must be in here somewhere.
I didn't think I'd live to see the day when you turned your back on your queen, but all things considered... good for you.
I didn't think I'd live to see the day when Lae'zel turned her back on Vlaakith, but all things considered... good for her.
'The Blade of Frontiers'. Let's hope Wyll lives up to his name - we'll need all the help we can get.
So, no deal with Raphael. I wouldn't want to give him the satisfaction, anyway.
I'm sorry, Gale. You tried. Mystra was wrong to turn on you, no matter what mistakes you made in the past.
Mystra was never worthy of your devotion, Gale. She will rue the day she turned on you, I am sure.
Jaheira's adept at keeping secrets - and for good reason. She was wise to try and keep her family safe... I just wish I could've done the same.
Jaheira's adept at keeping secrets - to conceal a family is no mean feat. Perhaps her skills lean more towards the Dark Lady than she realises...
We may need to increase our camp provisions now that we have Karlach along for the journey - those muscles don't run on fresh air, I'll wager. Still, she'll be useful in a fight.
Grand Duke-to-be, eh, Wyll? I hope you don't forget about us little people, after you've ascended.
Seems like Wyll's a Grand Duke-to-be. I hope he remembers us little people, after he's ascended.
I'll miss Astarion... though perhaps my neck won't.
Whatever Lady Shar bids me to. I must not fail her now - not when I'm so close...
It seems you have made up with Mystra, Gale. Congratulations. Lady Shar has no love for your goddess... but I am glad you have someone to turn to.
Orin's little display was just intended to rattle us. We mustn't let her succeed... but need to stay alert, all the same.
That cr√®che would be a smoking ruin if it wasn't for us. Still, better move along - I don't want to test the limits of githyanki gratitude.
So, the Stone Lord is Minsc, Jaheira's old acquaintance? Painfully small world, at times.
It feels like my entire world has been upended.
You had best hope Vlaakith appreciates your loyalty, Lae'zel. Otherwise I think you just killed a potential ally.
Lae'zel had better hope Vlaakith appreciates her loyalty. Otherwise, she achieved nothing but kill a potential ally.
We should be safe for the night now. Let's try and get some rest.
I can't believe Mystra actually expects Gale to just sacrifice himself like that. Seems like a waste of a fine mind.
I didn't expect you to turn on the Lich Queen so readily, Lae'zel. Wonders never cease.
I didn't expect Lae'zel to turn on the Lich Queen so readily. Wonders never cease.
We've had a mind flayer whispering to us in our dreams all this time...? I really shouldn't be surprised by anything at this stage.
Still... it seems keen to be an ally, in its own way. Compared to what we're up against, I'm not sure that's a bad thing.
So you remain loyal to your queen? You're consistent, I'll give you that...
So Lae'zel remains loyal to her queen? She's consistent, I'll give her that...
Karlach and Wyll seem to have put their differences aside. I thought it was going to come to blows for a moment.
This place seems remarkably tense for a sacred grove. Perhaps we shouldn't linger.
But let's at least see if there's a healer to be found, first of all.
It was no easy thing, overcoming those urges that gripped you. I'm not sure I would have managed, in your shoes. Well done.
There's nothing like a stroll through some sewers to keep your sense of self-importance in check.
Your father won't be around forever, Wyll. But the pact? That's a different matter. I hope you won't live to regret being sentimental.
It can't have been easy, to resign yourself to keeping the pact. But I'm glad you choose your father.
Wyll's father won't be around forever, but the pact? That's a different matter. I hope he won't live to regret being sentimental.
It can't have been easy, for Wyll to resign himself to the pact. But I'm glad he chose his father.
If this place is as inviting as other aspects of githyanki culture, we'll be in for an interesting time, to say the least...
That cr√®che would be a smoking ruin if it wasn't for us. Still, better move along - I don't want to test the limits of your peoples' gratitude.
I suppose Astarion is a part of the vampire aristocracy now. I hope he doesn't expect us to bow to him.
So, Jaheira is willing to embrace mortality - the ultimate form of retirement - and that's thanks to impressing her through your actions. Quite the compliment.
This place is quite a find. Imagine all the people going about their lives, unaware of what their city has hidden away.
We can't rely on the Harpers - not when Orin has them infested with shapeshifters. We're on our own - though I suppose we're used to it by now.
Wyrm's Crossing. We could be inside the city walls before long... and I could be back where this all started.
Be careful, consuming shadow magic. The darkness tends to take more than it gives. I would know.
You couldn't resist the allure of the shadows, Gale? I don't blame you - it's the only power that truly counts.
Orin's made off with Yenna. Either we mount a rescue... or we win her freedom with Gortash's life.
I think we've overstayed our welcome in this place - if we ever truly had one to begin with. We should leave.
Those vampire spawn came for you, didn't they Astarion? Good thing you're charming enough to fight for.
Those vampire spawn came for Astarion, didn't they? Lucky for him that we were here to fight them off...
The House of Hope - Raphael's abode. Only this time, he hasn't invited us to his table...
So, one dead devil, and you might learn something new about yourself, Astarion. Seems promising... if you trust Raphael, that is.
It seems Viconia sought a greater purpose than Lady Shar had decided for her.
Shar did not come to Viconia's defence. All who bow to her are disposable pawns, in the end.
Ironic. She tried to cling to Lady Shar's good graces, but that just hastened her downfall.
She should have just obeyed - forgotten about the artefact. Then perhaps she could have still served the Nightsinger... under me, of course.
The mission she sent me on was a lie - same as everything else she ever told me.
She sowed her own downfall in trying to take the prism for herself. Had she never sent me, I'd still bow to Shar, none the wiser...
Why the hells did she want the prism? It cost her everything.
No matter. Her loss is my gain. Lady Shar wills it.
No matter. I hope I never have to think of her again.
A goddess abandoning you needn't be the end, Gale. Trust me, I know.
I'm sorry, Gale. To be abandoned by your goddess... I cannot imagine how that must feel. May the Dark Lady comfort you.
